Headline: Barron's(1/15) 2007 Barron's Roundtable: Speaking Of Bubbles
Story: (From BARRON'S)     By Lauren R. Rublin   Call the cops! They almost came to blows this year, the dozen distinguished and mightily feisty members of our annual Roundtable. Still, it would be tough to find a group -- on Wall Street, especially -- with broader knowledge, deeper convictions and better debating skills than the investment pros who gathered Jan. 8 with the editors of Barron's to talk bulls, bears and bubbles, Apples and noodles, and everything else related to markets in 2007.     -- It's a bit hard tosum up this year's freewheeling discussion, which stretched way past happy hour and into the giddy hour. But it's clear Fred Hickey set the tone with his memorable opening line: "Goldilocks has imbibed a bit too much liquidity." (Wish we'd thought of that!)   -- Talk of money, money everywhere, and the bubbles it creates -- in housing, emerging markets, private equity, asset shufflers (they know who they are) -- dominated much of the macro discussion, giving rise to concerns that Goldie -- a.k.a. a "just right" economy and stock market -- would overheat and then grow cold.   -- Even so, a fair number of panelists don't expect the party to end this year. The sort-of-consensus view: U.S. stocks will rally "not much" to 8%-10% in '07, dividends included, though some see a violent shake-up along the way. Bonds won't be terribly interesting, and the dollar will continue to struggle.    -- We've tried to render the full flavor of the day's proceedings, verbal fisticuffs included, in this first of three Roundtable installments, which also features the stock picks of Scott Black and Art Samberg. Scott, whose love of great art is rivaled only by his fondness for low P/Es, offered up two energy issues and four "obscure" microcaps. Chances are you'll be glad you met them, and properly awed by his rigorous analysis, by the time you put down the page. Scott runs Boston-based Delphi Management.   Art, captain of Pequot Capital Management, a Westport, Conn.-based hedge fund, is a truly original thinker, as well as an eclectic investor. The two aren't unrelated. This year his thoughts ranged from the lure of alternative assets to the rebirth of Russia, and his picks from U.S. agriculture to Brazilian housing to a red-hot Chinese Internet play that he doesn't expect to cool -- yet.     Barron's: What do you think of the year we just had, and the year we are coming into? Fred, why don't you start?   Hickey: I liked the year but I didn't like the imbalances that continued to build. Goldilocks has imbibed a bit too much liquidity. The market hasn't had a 10% correction in four years, one of the longest runs in history. There hasn't been a 2% daily decline in the Dow in something like 920 days. It's been almost straight up since July. There is broad complacency, if not outright bullishness. Margin debt has returned to 2000 levels of about $270 billion.   In the midst of this euphoria, I see a sinking economy, led by housing. Housing permits are down 31% year over year. In the past 40 years, whenever permits plummeted like this, we've always had a recession. Housing prices are down 3% year over year. Cash-out-mortgage activity has collapsed by more than 50%. That's a $500 billion hit to consumer pocketbooks. Retail sales have weakened everywhere but at the high end. Transports have rolled over again. Auto sales are falling.     Samberg: Can I go home?   Hickey: Supposedly, services are going to save the economy, but as long as I've been around, fitness centers and investment bankers don't save the economy. The economy is sinking. That should hit earnings this year, and probably will lead to a rather steep decline in the stock market.     Q: So, you're bullish again. Abby?   Cohen: I find myself in disagreement with Fred.   Hickey: I'm not surprised.   Cohen: The economy isn't sinking; it's slowing and rotating. The housing sector has some significant problems, depending upon geography and which segment of the household sector we are talking about. Many lower-middle-income and lower-income families are in distress. But consumer spending as a whole has held up far better than almost anybody imagined. A lot of that is attributable to the strength of the labor market. Jobs are being created. Household incomes are growing. Energy prices have declined.   More important, economic growth is rotating into capital spending, business fixed investment and exports. In the past year, the global economy has been looking somewhat better. The sharp divergence between a robust U.S. and a lackluster environment in the other industrial economies has narrowed. Our export growth has picked up, particularly in categories related to high-level services and sophisticated capital goods. I don't think the economy is going into recession. Although many expect interest rates to move lower in 2007, I prefer to assume a less comfortable picture and plug rising interest rates into our equity-valuation models and asset allocation.     Q: And you, Art?   Samberg: If it ain't broke, don't fix it. I don't see where there's anything all that unusual. China is growing by 9%, 10%. India is growing slightly less. Brazil is growing at a nice rate. We have no inflation in the world. These countries are sucking up commodities, providing low-cost labor. Productivity is slowing but it is still decent. There's no major change in anything. The world economy is growing faster than anything we've ever seen before. In the long term, will jobs get outsourced and the U.S. lose its dominant position? Perhaps. It's a risk. But it ain't going to happen this year. As for housing, price inflation in the United States is no different from what it was in England and Australia, and those markets didn't see a collapse.   Zulauf: There's a difference, Art. The U.K. and Australian housing markets never had an inventory problem. Prices turned flat for 12 months, but inventories didn't go up.   Gabelli: Housing has had a typical cycle, with some excesses.   Gross: Excesses like we've never seen before. Home prices on a year-over-year basis are down 3.1%, according to the National Association of Realtors. We've never had a year-over-year decrease of this magnitude on a nominal basis.   Samberg: A 3% decline is something to worry about, but it doesn't change how the consumer thinks his balance sheet looks.   Cohen: There is a presumption, which is wrong, that all the mortgage-equity withdrawals were spent. In fact, a good deal of it was used to pay down other, higher-yielding debt, so balance sheets improved.   Hickey: We've been on a debt-based consumption binge forever. You people seem to think that can go on. It was a housing-bubble-driven thing, and prices now are falling. They are likely to continue to fall.   Cohen: Fred, personal-consumption growth exceeded 4%, and it's falling to 2%. That sounds like a significant slowdown factored into our economic forecast, but it is extraordinarily unusual for consumption ever to go negative. Maybe it did in the early '30s. The U.S. started 2006 with real GDP growth of 5%. This year it's about 2.5%.   Hickey: On the road from 4% to zero and negative, there is a stopover at 2%.     Q: Felix, what do you think?   Zulauf: It's very rare I agree with Abby.   Cohen: Only when you are being correct.   Zulauf: But I agree with her. The U.S. economy will have a pronounced slowdown, but will not go into a recession this year. There will be some disappointments. A market that has gone up for four years without a major correction will undergo some correction. If it occurs now it will be mild. If it occurs later in the year from a higher level, it could be brutal. We have to reload for a continuation of the trends we have seen in world markets and the world economy, though eventually they will reach mania proportions and we will have the usual worldwide recession and major economic crisis we see nearly every decade.     Q: Then you don't quite agree with Abby. Oscar?   Schafer: We are mostly stock pickers. I am surprised by the strength of the economy. As far as housing is concerned, the number of people who are employed and have jobs is more important. The consumer has the view that if he's employed now, he'll be employed next year. If the person next door to him has a job, he'll continue to spend.   But a few elements in the economy are different. Where companies once used their cash flow to build plants, they are now outsourcing manufacturing to China and India. When demand turns down, instead of having layoffs in the U.S. and the cyclical elements Fred talked about, the cycles will become more muted. Companies will call their suppliers in Hong Kong and Mumbai and tell them to stop shipping. Because of this, cash flows at U.S. companies are higher than historically, and will stay that way. The beneficiary is the consumer, who benefits from lower-priced imports. The economy this year will continue to muddle along. The stock market will have a correction, but not do much, net, on the year.   Hickey: The biggest driver of job growth in the past six years was the housing market. Now it is seeing its biggest decline in 15 years or more. Unemployment is the laggingest of indicators. It is the reason why the Fed is always wrong. Historically the Fed has taken too long to cut interest rates because it has looked at lagging indicators.   Black: It looks at a bundle. The bottom line is, consumption has held up, notwithstanding the decline in housing. Personal-consumption expenditures in the third quarter were up 2.8% on a real basis. Durable-goods orders were up. Housing was bad. It has knocked 1.5 percentage points off GDP growth. But the bad news is out.   Zulauf: Housing declines have lasted on average two-and-a-half to four years.   Gabelli: There is not only a decline, but an overhang as production comes down. It's the same as in the auto industry.     Mario, what is your outlook for this year?   (MORE TO FOLLOW) Dow Jones Newswires  January 13, 2007 00:03 ET (05:03 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Headline: Barron's(1/15) Editorial Commentary: The Royal CEO, Part II
Story: (From BARRON'S)     By Thomas G. Donlan   Last week, we defended Apple from the charge that Steve Jobs benefitted from backdating a set of stock options. We said no sensible shareholder would be happy if he were thrown to the wolves.   Jobs, however, is a special case. Few American executives are so closely identified with the creation and development of their companies and their products.   This week, we take up the more unpopular case of Home Depot's former royal CEO. Robert L. Nardelli was a hired gun,like most other CEOs. He was a graduate of the merciless General Electric school of management. He was an executive of a corporation he did not build. Indeed, Home Depot's board of directors had hired him away from General Electric to replace the company's popular co-founders.   Nardelli recently was hounded from office by members of the shareholders' rights movement. They criticized him for taking an extravagant pay package without delivering a rising stock price. They found him high-handed and stubbornly unwilling to communicate with them, especially at the 2006 annual meeting.   Ironically, he received more money for leaving than he had for working. His severance package is apparently worth more than $200 million, although a good deal of it is deferred. Negotiated in 2000, when the board was eager to entice him on board, the package looks more like a poison-pill defense against being fired than a gold-watch reward for long service. Yet in the end, it failed to preserve his job.   The New York Times declared: "There was good news and bad news for shareholders of Home Depot. The good news is that Robert Nardelli, the imperious chief executive who had presided over a difficult, stagnant period for the company, has resigned. The bad news is that he'll be taking $210 million worth of compensation with him."   Difficult, yes. Stagnant? It depends. Home Depot stock crashed from 70 to 21 along with the broad market in 2001, but recovered some of the loss in 2003, and has fluctuated since. The stock is down nearly 20% from Nardelli's arrival. But at 40, it's 100% above its low at the beginning of 2003.   Operating numbers are interesting. When Nardelli arrived in 2000, Home Depot had $45.7 billion of sales at 1,134 stores. This year, the company is nearly twice as big, by both measures. Earnings were $1.10 a share in fiscal 2001, and are on track for $2.91 in fiscal 2007 (ending Jan. 31 each year). The annual dividend more than tripled, to 60 cents a share, and the company did $13.3 billion worth of stock buybacks through the third quarter ended Oct. 31, 2006. All told, 65% of the company's earnings were paid to shareholders from 2002 through 2006 -- more than $15 billion -- while shareholders' equity rose from $15 billion to $26.9 billion.   It is far too early to tell if Nardelli's departure constitutes good news for Home Depot's investors.   It is very easy to tell, however, that Home Depot became bigger and stronger while Nardelli was at the helm. (Do his critics have the company's best interests at heart?)   It is also easy to tell that Nardelli's compensation package should not have been a hot concern for shareholders -- $210 million is about 10 cents a share. That may be material, but it's not overwhelming in the face of more than $12 a share earned during Nardelli's tenure -- to say nothing of any future earnings flowing from his acquisitions and projects.   A current theory of the shareholder-rights movement is that serious capitalists can make big profits by purchasing the depressed shares of poorly run companies, and then pushing the CEOs and boards of those companies to make important changes that would turn the companies around in business and the stock market.   One such capitalist is Ralph V. Whitworth, who formed a hedge fund to invest in companies he deemed poorly managed by overcompensated executives. The California Public Employees' Retirement System is one of his biggest investors. The fund, called Relational Investors, reportedly has $7 billion invested in nine companies, including $1 billion in Home Depot.   As a hedge fund, Relational Investors makes no financial disclosures to the outside world that would satisfy its own standard for corporations. Presumably, it keeps Calpers and its other investors abreast of its market decisions. To the public, the fund simply declares that it has "materially outperformed" its benchmark, the Standard & Poor's 500's total return over the years from 1996 to 2005.   Skeptics should question whether that's an appropriate benchmark for a fund that aims to invest in eight to 12 stocks and take positions worth up to 10% of each company's market-capitalization. Such a fund is inescapably more risky than an S&P index fund, and ought to be compared to something nearer its own backyard, like the number seven on a roulette table.   We should distrust pension funds that gamble with their participants' money at least as much as we distrust executives who won't answer questions at annual meetings. We hold Calpers in particular in minimum high regard anyway, for it often seems more beholden to its participants' unions and and their political agendas than to sound fiduciary principles.   Calpers should get off its high horse and buy bonds (although not California bonds) to match its liabilities. Even if its stewards remain enthralled with equities and speculating in corporate-governance strategies, those who do not like classified boards, poison pills, imperious CEOs, servile boards and so on have a much simpler route to profit than investment in a noisy, undiversified hedge fund. They can sell the stock of the companies with which they disagree and keep investments in the other companies in the S&P 500. If they want to incur enormous risk, they can even sell shares short. They also can buy the stock of the competitors to those companies they dislike.   Calpers fiduciaries should note that Whitworth's Relational Investors and its allies could have made more money sooner by quietly buying Lowe's -- the recovering former industry leader, now about half the size of Home Depot -- than by owning Home Depot shares and forcing out the CEO.   ---   For Barron's subscription information call 1-888-BARRONS ext. 685 or inquire online at http://www.barronsmag.com/subscription/subscription.html.     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  January 13, 2007 00:08 ET (05:08 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Headline: Barron's(1/15) A Green Light For Yellow
Story: (From BARRON'S)     By Tom Sullivan   "Knocked down, it gets to wearin' thin," goes the Grateful Dead's ballad "Truckin."   That also describes the stock of freight-carrier YRC Worldwide, the former Yellow Roadway. The shares (ticker: YRCW), now near 40, are down about 10% since mid-November, historically the peak time for truckers as retailers build up inventory ahead of the holidays.   So despite an uncertain outlook for the economy and the trucking industry, the stock looks cheap -- maybe even dirtcheap. The shares got a lift recently as oil prices hit an 18-month low, cutting trucks' fuel costs. And if the economy can resume decent growth, the company and the entire sector should get a boost.   YRC, based in Overland Park, Kan., is one of the world's largest freight-transportation service providers, with brands including Yellow Transportation, Roadway, Reimer Express, USF, New Penn Motor Express and Meridian IQ. The company ships industrial, commercial and retail goods domestically and internationally. It operates some 100,000 tractor-trailers, 90% of which it owns, and has north of 800,000 customers. Its shares have a market value around $2.233 billion.   In mid-December, YRC stunned the stock market by lowering its fourth-quarter earnings estimate to a range of 95 cents to $1.05 a share, down from $1.40 to $1.50. YRC also sliced its 2006 full-year earnings outlook to $5 to $5.10 a share, from $5.45 to $5.55.   The company blamed a slowing economy. Chief Executive Bill Zollars said tonnage trucked was down across all of YRC's business units and that pricing was "somewhat below" what the company had expected, as retailers kept a close eye on inventories.   Zollars now contends that the freight transporter's stock is "very undervalued," and vows that he will focus on cost reductions and global initiatives to lift the shares and improve the company's results. YRC will "follow our customers around the world," he tells Barron's.   YRC will release 2006 financial results on Feb. 1, and that could mark a turning point.   "November tonnage for the industry was down 8.8%," says John Neff, former portfolio manager of Vanguard Windsor and a member of the Barron's Roundtable  Given "how dismal the industry is," YRC's announcement last month "doesn't sound that bad," he maintains.   Neff sees the company earning $4 a share in 2007 if there's a recession, but he says it's more likely that YRC can earn $5.75 to $6, assuming that U.S. economic growth continues to chug along at a 2.5% annual clip. That would make for a price-earnings ratio of just seven, versus 11 to 13 for the trucking industry as a whole.   Just by closing the valuation gap with it peers, YRC's shares could climb more than 50% from their recent 39.   Without question, the company is a solid cash generator. In the past 12 months, it produced some $884 million in cash flow, up 11% from 2005. That helped it to pay down an estimated $200 million of debt last year.   Credit-rating agency Standard & Poor's, in a recent research note, said that YRC's operating margins are solid and that its business-risk profile is "satisfactory because it has a leading market share." The company also has "a small, but growing, China operation," which is taking advantage of that booming economy, S&P said.     Zollars says the company has two Chinese joint-venture partners to help it navigate China's rocky political terrain. He also says the company will pay down "at least" another $200 million of debt this year.   Ronald Muhlenkamp, portfolio manager and founder of Muhlenkamp & Co., made a name for himself picking trucking stocks 30 years ago, and his fund owns YRC, which he considers undervalued. "It's cheap; it has been cheap," he says. "We own it primarily because of that."   Many in the market are much less sanguine. Analysts at Bear Stearns last month lowered their 2007 estimates to $4.08 from $4.13, considerably lower than Neff's projection. "With weakening tonnage and a materially more competitive market, we believe the next shoe to drop for [YRC] . . . could likely be pricing," the analysts wrote.   One frequently cited problem: underfunded pension liabilities. The company has $2.5 billion to $3.5 billion in potential liability, related just to the Teamsters' Central States Pension Fund, Bear Stearns points out.   Neff, however, views these concerns as overblown. The pension obligations, he argues, "are up in the air" and may ultimately be paid by the Teamsters.   And despite growing competition from railroads and United Parcel Service (UPS) and FedEx (FDX), Muhlenkamp says there's plenty of room for everybody to profit. "If railroads and trucks do well, Yellow will get its share" of the business, he contends.   With any luck, this trip, unlike the Grateful Dead's, will be neither long nor strange.   ---   For Barron's subscription information call 1-888-BARRONS ext. 685 or inquire online at http://www.barronsmag.com/subscription/subscription.html.     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  January 13, 2007 00:08 ET (05:08 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Headline: Venezuela Pres:Cos May Own Minority Stakes In Oil Projects
Story: CARACAS (AP)--President Hugo Chavez said Saturday that his government will allow private companies to own minority stakes in lucrative Orinoco River basin oil projects that Venezuela plans to nationalize.   Chavez announced plans earlier this week for the state to take control of the country's largest telecommunications company, its electricity and natural gas sectors and four heavy crude upgrading projects now controlled by some of the world's top oil companies.   It hadn't been clear whether Chavez intended the state to have total control of the projects or a majority stake as his government had previously said.   In a speech to congress Saturday, Chavez said the private companies - British Petroleum PLC (BP), Exxon Mobil Corp. (XOM), Chevron Corp. (CVX), ConocoPhillips Co. (COP), Total SA (TOT) and Statoil ASA (STO) - would be given the option to stay on as minority partners.   "He who wants to stay on as our partner, we'll leave open the possibility to him. He who doesn't want to stay on as a minority partner, hand over the (oil) field and, goodbye," he said.   "Goodbye, good luck and thank you very much," Chavez added in English.   Chavez's government has already taken majority ownership of all other oil-producing operations in the country through joint ventures controlled by the state oil company. Most companies have shown a willingness to continue investing despite the tightening terms.     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  January 13, 2007 13:00 ET (18:00 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Headline: China: Drafting Rules On Foreign Stock Exchange Offices
Story: BEIJING (Dow Jones)--China's securities regulator is drafting rules on the establishment of foreign stock exchange representative offices in the country, a prerequisite for NYSE Group Inc. (NYX) and Nasdaq Stock Market Inc. (NDAQ) to open formal offices here, a senior Chinese regulator said Saturday.   "After we complete the regulations, foreign stock exchanges will be able to apply to set up representative offices in China," Tu Guangshao, vice chairman of the China Securities Regulatory Commission, told reporters on the sidelines of a conference in Beijing.   China agreed to allow Nasdaq Stock Market and NYSE Group, operator of the New York Stock Exchange, to expand their presence in China at the first meeting of the U.S.-China Strategic Economic Dialogue held Dec. 14-15 in Beijing.   Tu didn't give a specific timetable for when the regulations would be completed or how long the application process would take.   Dozens of Chinese companies have listed shares on Nasdaq and the New York Stock Exchange, and both are eager for more business in the country as China's economy booms.   Some Chinese firms have been reluctant to list shares in the U.S. citing costly regulatory requirements and have instead turned to the Hong Kong stock exchange to tap the international capital market.   Industrial & Commercial Bank of China Ltd., the country's biggest bank by assets, completed the world's largest initial public offering in October by selling $22 billion worth of shares on the Hong Kong and Shanghai exchanges.     -By Rick Carew, Dow Jones Newswires; 8610 6588-5848; rick.carew@dowjones.com     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  January 13, 2007 05:33 ET (10:33 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Headline: Barron's(1/15) Fund Of Information: Spotlight's On Index Funds' Expenses
Story: (From BARRON'S)     By Lawrence C. Strauss   One would think that all index funds have similar operating expenses. The Standard & Poor's 500 doesn't vary from one fund to another, after all.   But not all index funds are alike when it comes to expenses. That's partly because the bigger ones have more scale, enabling them to spread their costs over more assets and reduce operating costs for shareholders.   Expense ratios of S&P 500 index funds range from 0.07% to 1.45%, according to a recent study.   In addition, the study asserts, brokers too often put their clients into funds with higher operating expenses. The Investment Company Institute, the mutual-fund industry's trade association, disputes that. It maintains that the study is flawed.   The study, by Mercer Bullard of shareholder-advocacy group Fund Democracy and Edward S. O'Neal of the Babcock Graduate School of Management at Wake Forest University, was commissioned by the Zero Alpha Group, a network of investment advisers. It maintains that, on an asset-weighted basis, the average adjusted operating expenses for load funds is 0.704%, compared with 0.215% for no-load funds with no 12b-1 fees.   That's a big difference and, if correct, very costly to fund shareholders. (12b-1 fees, which come out of a fund's net asset value, and loads, or sales charges, are used in large part to pay brokers for advice and service. The 12b-1 fees are ongoing.)   "The important question is not why certain funds are more expensive, but why investors who receive investment advice from brokers invest in more expensive funds," the study's authors observe.   The ICI, however, disputes the study's premise that 35.5% of 12b-1 fees go toward fund operating expenses. Operating expenses, besides the management fee, include various administrative tasks such as record-keeping.   The Investment Company Institute's chief economist, Brian Reid, maintains that "only 2% of the 12b-1 fee is used for promotion and advertising. The rest is paying for distribution and compensation for financial advisers, and these are services above and beyond those being offered to a no-load investor."   With 12b-1 fees excluded from the calculation, the study's operating expenses for load funds average closer to 0.42%, around the industry norm, Reid argues.   Part of the issue is that Vanguard, whose expense ratios are very low relative to most other firms', does not open its core index funds to the traditional broker sales model involving loads and 12b-1 fees. Its exchange-traded funds are sold on a commission basis.   Bullard says that the study's assumptions regarding the 12b-1 fees are correct, save for some minor points, and in fact are based on research by the Investment Company Institute.   We will let the study's authors and the ICI battle this one out. However, regardless of who is correct, it's clear that index-fund investors should be acutely aware of how much they are paying in operating expenses as well as sales charges.     Marty Whitman, whose forays into distressed debt and other corners of the deep-value universe have led to strong returns, has anointed a successor of the fund he runs, Third Avenue Value (ticker: TAVFX). But Whitman insists he isn't going anywhere right now.   In a recent letter to shareholders, Whitman, 82, announced that Ian Lapey, who has been with the New York investment firm for nearly six years, will succeed him.   Third Avenue Value has generated strong returns over the years. Its 10-year annual return of 13.50% bests the S&P 500 by more than five percentage points. He's made some astute calls on beaten-down securities, including Kmart senior notes in 2002. "He's demanded a lot from companies in terms of their responsibilities to shareholders," says Kerry O'Boyle, a fund analyst at Morningstar.   For all of his success, Whitman readily acknowledges that distressed investing doesn't always pan out. In his note to shareholders, Whitman said that the fund's $153 million investment in bankrupt auto-parts supplier Collins & Aikman Products' senior notes is likely to result in close to a "total loss."     It's been widely reported that Bill Miller, the longtime manager of Legg Mason Value Trust (LMVTX), saw his 15-year winning streak broken at the end of last year when his portfolio failed to beat the S&P 500.   But one bad year has a ripple effect on performance. Late last week, Value Trust's three-year annual return of 7.37% trailed the S&P 500's by 2.62 percentage point, placing it in the bottom 13% of its category. Headline: Barron's(1/15) Follow-Up: Will Toyota Stk Stay In Fast Lane?
Story: (From BARRON'S)     By Jay Palmer   Two years ago, we posed a simple question: "Can Anyone Stop Toyota?" read a headline in the Sept. 13, 2004, edition. The answer, as we suspected at the time, is a resounding "No."   As sales tumbled for Detroit's Big Three in 2006, Toyota Motors snapped up a 15.4% share of the giant U.S. market, roaring past DaimlerChrysler to become the third-largest auto seller. The Japanese giant is likely to grab the No. 2 spot from Ford Motor (ticker: F) this summer, then take on market leader General Motors (GM).   Thanks to Toyota's impressive global plant productivity, the story in Europe and the emerging Asian markets is much the same -- and all the sales gains come without Toyota resorting to profit-sapping incentives.   Little wonder that Toyota's American depositary receipts (TM) shot up 28% last year and rang in 2007 by hitting a record $137.77. Although the price has eased back down to about 128, that's still 68% above where it was when we ran that 2004 story.   Toyota is moving to keep up the momentum with new models like the 2007 Tundra, a hefty, made-in-Texas pickup that's strikingly more stylish than most Toyota trucks.   In Toyota's current fiscal year, which ends in March, analysts are looking for earnings to climb about 22%, to 490 yen per share (about $4.07), and perhaps rise even faster in the following two years. Shotaro Noguchi, an analyst with Mitsubishi UFJ Securities, points out that capital spending on plants has been easing, meaning "sales growth now will be directly reflected in earnings gains."   Even after the shares' runup, they are trading at just 14.1 times year-ahead earnings -- lower than the multiple of Honda Motors (HMC) and hardly a high price to pay for a company set to become No. 1 worldwide.   True, the gains in stock price this year are unlikely to match the torrid pace of 2006, Noguchi and other analysts say. The company's improved prospects are now better reflected in the shares. But the price gains are still apt to be healthy; one bull even sees a gain of about 10%. And in the auto industry these days, that's saying a lot.   ---   For Barron's subscription information call 1-888-BARRONS ext. 685 or inquire online at http://www.barronsmag.com/subscription/subscription.html.     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  January 13, 2007 00:08 ET (05:08 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

If you have 5% loan growth next year and a 5% increase in non-interest income, you get earnings of about $1.85 a share. If you have 8% loan growth with 8% non-interest income, you get about $1.95. The mid-point is $1.90. The bank recently hired a marketing executive. It is going to start advertising and become more aggressive in seeking commercial deposits. Most regional banks are selling at 13 to 14 multiples and don't have numbers like Severn's.     Q: Thank you, Scott. Let's hear from Art.   Samberg: For many years I came to this gathering and Mario talked about the U.S. as an agricultural society.     Q: He comes from a farming background.   Gabelli: There are a lot of farms in the Bronx.   Samberg: His point was America has a competitive advantage in agriculture, and he's right. Last year, I talked about Monsanto [MON] It was a winner, but there is more to go. Everyone woke up to the fact that ethanol is huge. Corn exploded. Prices paid to farmers are going way up. They are in great shape. You could get a pullback in corn prices but it's not going to mean anything because the farmers are going to plant. Monsanto is on an August year. In the first quarter net income rose 53%. Last year part of my case for the stock was built on corn seeds going from single- to dual- to triple-stack [genetic] traits. Monsanto and Syngenta [SYT] and DuPont [DD] make 2 1/2 times the gross margins on a triple stack as they would on a single stack. Last year, 5.8 million acres were planted with triple traits, up from one million. Monsanto is the dominant company.   In addition, their R&D pipeline has gotten more robust. The progress they've made on drought-resistant traits is stunning. They have also developed a soy seed that has no trans fats. Michael Bloomberg will buy it. [New York City recently banned most trans fats in restaurant cooking.]     Q: Where is the stock?   Samberg: It's right around 50, and earnings are going to be $1.60. But they always underpromise and overdeliver. They generate over a billion dollars of free cash a year.   Gabelli: The corn farmer just saw a $1.50 increase in his price per bushel.   Samberg: He is coining money. On that note, I'm recommending cotton -- the December '07 contract. This is the other side of the growth story in agriculture. You're a farmer and you want to plant cotton? You've got to be crazy. You want to plant corn or wheat. Cotton consumption in the U.S. has fallen from 12 million to five million bales a year because of the growth of polyester and other stuff. But the real story is China, as it is with most things. In China, there is a booming fixed-asset investment across the textile industry. Spending in China was up 27% in '06, after rising 36% in '05. Chinese consumption of cotton had been growing by 4%-6% a year. Now it's growing by 15% a year. China's consumption of cotton has gone from 25% to 39%-40% of world cotton consumption. They are a large importer.   The decline in U.S. cotton consumption had masked some of these trends. U.S. farmers are going to withdraw acreage. There have been only four times since 1913 when cotton was this cheap relative to grains like corn and wheat. The last time was in 1974, and farmers planted 16% less cotton acreage the next year. From the end of '74 to mid-'76, the cotton price tripled.     Q: What's next?   Jumping to Brazil, I recommended CVRD [Companhia Vale do Rio Doce, RIO] two years ago. It remains attractive because they bought Inco, one of the world's largest nickel producers, and nobody has bothered to factor in the accretive earnings power of Inco. The purity of CVRD's grain of iron ore is up at about 66%-67%. In China, when they mine for iron ore, the quality of the grain is about 18%. They need a lot of water to process that low quality, and it causes smog. You're going to see a shut-down of Chinese iron ore production. The only incremental production in the world is from CVRD. BHP Billiton can't produce more. Rio Tinto can't produce more. CVRD still is not appreciated based on the robustness of its iron ore position, and it just stole Inco.   There are other stories like that in Brazil. Though Lula [Brazilian President Luiz Inacio Lula da Silva] has frightened everybody by railing against privatization, the Brazilian economy is doing well. My next picks are two Brazilian home builders that went public last year: Gafisa and Brascan Residential Properties. The high-end housing market is just developing because Brazil never had mortgages before. All of 36,000 mortgages were offered in 2003. Last year, there were 100,000, and that is going to rise by 50% a year for the next two years. The Selic rate, or the Brazilian mortgage rate, was 23% in '03. Last year it was 15% and it looks like it's coming down because interest rates in Brazil are coming down. There is also a shortage of housing units in Brazil.     Q: Where do these stocks trade?   Samberg: They trade on the Bovespa. Sam Zell is a big minority holder. He owns about 24% of Gafisa. There is a housing deficit in Brazil of about seven million to eight million houses. The deficit at the high end is about 1.5 million. The population in the past 60 years has gone from countryside to the cities. Brazil is now 80% urban; that's why there's a housing deficit. Gafisa and Brascan have a 5% to 10% market share in Rio and Sao Paulo.   Next, education. The for-profit education stocks -- Apollo Group [APOL], Career Education [CECO] and Corinthian Colleges [COCO] -- were growth stocks, but ran into problems. They were shorts for a couple of years. I think they've bottomed and the fundamentals are starting to improve. Apollo is the largest university in the U.S. through its University of Phoenix system, which is actually a good educational franchise. They have about 270,000 enrollees a year. They used to grow 30% a year, but one of the problems of tight employment is that people don't see the need to go back to school. As this market has slowed, Apollo has entered the community-college market via Axia College of the University of Phoenix. This is a two-year program online, and the company has been spending money like mad. Apollo earns about $2.50 a share, and the stock trades for 40. It is selling for about 16 times this year's earnings. The free-cash-flow yield will be about 7.2% this year. The company has about $3.50 per share of excess cash and no debt, 173 million shares and a market cap of about $6.9 billion.     Q: What did they earn last year?   Samberg: About the same. Earnings are not doing much. But the company is spending $2.50 a share on Axia, and now has about 80,000 students. They launched it in '04, and it is now the third-largest community college in the U.S. It has a 32% graduation rate, two times the national average. If you think of it as a feeder system to the four-year program at the University of Phoenix, it is a very low acquisition cost per student. It is a good company, and the momentum will start to build in the next year or two. If the Axia story works, Apollo has $4-$5 a share of earnings power. Career and Corinthian are vocational-type schools.   MacAllaster: Which do you like best?   Samberg: I like Apollo. Career was a disaster to the point where the Department of Education sanctioned them. They supposedly are not allowed to add any new schools or new programs. The company has said that this month or next they will have a new CEO. That's an important part of the story. The old management grew the company through acquisitions but didn't put in the proper procedures and the quality of the product suffered. They had accreditation problems in the South. Last August they quietly opened two schools in the South with DOE approval. They will probably get full accreditation by December.   This is a valuable property. The stock sells for 25 and has earnings power of $2.50 a share. I don't usually do turnarounds, but these things are very LBO-able in that they have a lot of cash and decent earnings power.     Q: What about Corinthian?   Samberg: It's much further along. It has a great CEO, Jack Massimino, who joined in 2004. He whittled it down from 28 to five different kinds of schools. Enrollment growth is flattish. This is a broken industry that fits a need the country has.   My last pick is Baidu.com [BIDU], the Chinese search-engine company. The multiple is obscene. I haven't done anything like this in a while, but it's sort of fun doing it again. The company sells for 64 times earnings. It is the dominant search-engine company in China. It has a 60% market share versus Google's [GOOG] 25 to 30. Yahoo! [YHOO] has about a 5% share. Sohu, a Chinese company, has a 2%-3% share. Baidu has everything going for it. It is growing 170% year over year. The stock trades for 122, and they will earn $1.95 a share this year. The Street is at $1.75. Baidu introduced a new search algorithm in the second quarter that is far better than anybody else's, but slowed sales. A new direct-sales- force model also slowed things down.   So far, Baidu's market penetration is low: There are only 100,000 customers. But 4.2 million enterprises could use its service to sell advertising. Ad spending is one-fortieth of what it is in the U.S. The comany could grow by 100% a year for the next three to five years. It sounds expensive at 64 times earnings, but I don't think it is. With the new algorithm and direct-sales force, growth will reaccelerate.     Q: Art, what do you think of tech?   Samberg: I leave that for Fred. I like cotton. There are far fewer opportunities in tech, though this is probably the year of WiFi. To me, General Electric [GE] is a far more interesting company than a semiconductor company.     Q: Thanks.   ---   For Barron's subscription information call 1-888-BARRONS ext. 685 or inquire online at http://www.barronsmag.com/subscription/subscription.html.     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  January 13, 2007 00:04 ET (05:04 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.
