Headline: US Fedl Probes Into Allied Capital Unit Are Growing-NYT
Story: NEW YORK (Dow Jones)--U.S. federal investigations into small-business loans issued by a unit of the Allied Capital (ALD) are growing, as a former executive of the unit faces fraud charges in Michigan, the New York Times reported in its Saturday editions.   Federal investigators are now looking at loans issued by the unit, Business Loan Express, in other parts of the country, according to several people briefed on the investigation, the Times reported.   The federal Small Business Administration - which typically guarantees 75% of the value of these small-business loans - is considering suspending the preferred lending status of Business Loan Express, pending the outcome of an investigation, the report said. That would mean that every loan Business Loan Express issues would have to be vetted by the agency, those people said, the Times reported.   The S.B.A. this week also suspended the unit's ability to sell the loans it issues to large institutional investors in the secondary market, which could affect the ability of Business Loan Express to make loans, those people said, according to the Times. The unit can still originate loans, but only if it intends to hold those loans on its own books, which is not something the firm has historically done, the report said.   Allied Capital's former executive, Patrick J. Harrington, is accused of falsifying information on 76 loans with a value of nearly $77 million over six years, according to an indictment that was handed up on Wednesday by a federal grand jury in Michigan, the report said. Harrington has not entered a plea to the charges, the report said.     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  January 13, 2007 07:08 ET (12:08 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Headline: Barron's(1/15) For Europe, Another Big Buyout Year Ahead
Story: (From BARRON'S)     By Vito J. Racanelli   Though European equities have soared about 125% over the past four years, activity in mergers and acquisitions and in leveraged buyouts should continue at a brisk pace on the Continent in 2007. They'll be fueled by low global interest rates, strong corporate balance sheets, slowing but still healthy earnings growth and historically undemanding equity valuations.   Deals will grow bigger, more expensive and riskier this year, many investors and analysts contend, so chances are the bull market in M&A may soon enter the late innings of the cycle. Nevertheless, as our nearby screens of M&A and LBO candidates suggest, there remain plenty of potential targets in Europe. Except for the large-caps, which we'll discuss below, these stocks generally fit the classic LBO profile: small-to-mid caps, with low debt, good cash levels and steady cash flows in noncyclical, prosaic industries.   Around the world, money is sloshing about. Both private-equity funds and corporations sit on tons of cash, and the cost of debt remains favorable. Right now, "the estimated 2007 European-equity free-cash-flow yield is 6.5%, while the cost of credit is about 5%," notes Hasan Tevfik, a London-based Citigroup strategist. As long as that profitable spread persists, "de-equitization" -- as Citigroup refers to M&A, LBOs and share buybacks -- will be a notable feature of the European stock landscape.   Last year, announced European M&A and LBOs jumped 38%, to $1.4 trillion, roughly similar to both the worldwide rise and that seen in North America, according to Thomson Financial. A repeat of that huge percentage gain isn't expected in 2007, but many believe last year's totals will be topped.   Currently, European stocks trade at a price-earnings ratio of about 13 times 2007 consensus estimates, below the historical average of 14.5. The region's earnings growth is forecast at a still respectable 8% next year, though slowing from about 15% in 2006. That, however, should encourage some companies -- especially in sectors where profit expansion is weakening -- to prowl for targets offering earnings growth.   "There's plenty of appetite" for deals on the part of corporate buyers, says Lars Kreckel, an ABN Amro analyst. European companies exhibit strong business confidence, record profitability, and impressive "balance-sheet firepower," he says, the result of debt reduction over the past four years. And debt markets remain "very open" to lending for deals, he adds.   In terms of M&A, what has been telling is the stock market's reaction to announced mergers, says the ABN analyst. Shares of proposed acquirers have not suffered as much as in the past, and some have even risen, he adds.   On the private-equity side, more LBO funds are targeting Europe and non-U.S. assets, adds Louise Purtle, an analyst at CreditSights, an independent research firm. The U.S., she notes, has been picked over and is burdened by greater competition for "LBOable" assets. That favors Europe as a region with many small- and mid-caps that are potential targets.   War chests are piling up, she adds. And there's an increased prevalence of "club deals," where bigger LBO targets are taken down by a gaggle of LBO funds. While the "national champions" are unlikely targets, "you could see $50 billion-$60 billion deals in Europe this year," adds Kreckel. Bigger companies are now potential targets.   Purtle sees telecoms, whose stocks have underperformed for several years, as vulnerable. Indeed, a number, like Telekom Austria (ticker: TKA AV.Vienna) and Greece's OTE (OTE), have shown up on LBO screens. "It's difficult to do but can be done, as evidenced by the deal for TDC AS," she says, referring to the Danish telecom incumbent bought out last year by private equity firms for about 13 billion euros (almost $17 billion).   There's roughly $250 billion of uninvested capital out there, which, when combined with the typical debt leverage of 3 or 4 to 1, suggests that at least $1 trillion around the world is looking for a home.   One of the most significant changes investors should watch for in 2007 is bigger deals, another sign, perhaps, that the bull is aging. "Deals are getting larger, riskier and more expensive," says Gregory Peters, Morgan Stanley's head of credit research.   The increased risk is a consequence of both higher multiples and improved appetite for more cyclical businesses, which don't fit the textbook LBO screen for stable cash flows. "Asset-rich businesses are still preferred . . . but targets are less traditional," says Peters. He and others expect a deal of $50 billion or above this year.   The most common buyout metric has been enterprise value (net debt plus market capitalization) to earnings before interest, taxes, depreciation and amortization. Historically, a target EV/Ebitda ratio of eight times or below made deals sensible, though cash-flow yield and debt levels are important, too, says Kreckel. (Most of the small- and mid-cap stocks in the nearby table trade at eight times or below.) The average deal ratio rose to above eight times in 2006 from about seven in 2004. And Krackel points out that lately there have been deals with infrastructure-type targets where EV/Ebidtda multiples have been in excess of 10, and even 13.   That cyclical businesses are no longer off limits is evidenced by the bid for Australia's Qantas airline in mid-December by Macquarie Bank and U.S. private-equity group Texas Pacific.   The Barron's list of potential candidates is compiled from stocks common to LBO screens published recently by ABN Amro, Citigroup and CreditSights.   Among the small- and mid-caps, there are many companies in unflashy industries with stable cash flows like telecoms, utilities, construction and media. For example, Italcementi (IT IM.Milan), Italy's largest construction company, has lately seen strong sales in the Mediterranean region and Asia. And Terna (TRN IM.Milan) operates Italy's power grid, a business that is about as stable as it gets.   Media are well-represented by U.K. newspaper publisher Trinity Mirror (TNI LN.London), which is under increasing pressure to improve shareholder returns. The company recently said that groups have inquired about buying some of its assets. And London-based Pearson (PSON LN.London) is a textbook publisher.   Among large-caps, there is Barclays (BCS), a global bank that's been the subject of recurring rumors of interest from Bank of America (BAC) -- rumors the latter has tried to dampen. And there's Volkswagen (VLKAY), the giant German carmaker in which Porsche bought a 27% stake last year, sparking speculation it might launch a takeover bid.   LBO screens, of course, are not a way to pick single stocks. Few or perhaps none of these companies will be taken over this year. A portfolio approach, as Citigroup's Tevfik's proposes, is better. These stocks don't have to receive a bid to rise. Just being in the "M&A candidate space" will exert pressure on managements to improve shareholder returns, he says. And in the long run, "value tends to outperform."   Though most investors are looking for another robust year of deals, there are signs the deal-making might be peaking in 2007. Though they are still low, interest rates are rising and earnings growth is slowing, notes Arielle Levi, a fund manager at DNCA Finance in Paris, so "risks are rising" for LBO funds.   Adds Joseph Quinlan, Bank of America's chief market strategist: "There are signs the cycle is turning. Deals and premiums are getting bigger." Quinlan believes that global liquidity will tighten in the second half and quarter-on-quarter deal comparisons will begin to decline in 2008.   For now, however, it's "Laissez le bon temps roulez."   ---   For Barron's subscription information call 1-888-BARRONS ext. 685 or inquire online at http://www.barronsmag.com/subscription/subscription.html.     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  January 13, 2007 00:09 ET (05:09 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Headline: Barron's(1/15) Tech Trader: The Inner Workings Of InnerWorkings
Story: (From BARRON'S)     By Bill Alpert   In a road show continuing this week, Morgan Stanley hopes to persuade investors to part with $150 million for the follow-on stock offering of a company called InnerWorkings. This Chicago-based company claims that its proprietary software is radically changing how American companies procure print jobs. In just the five months since their initial offering, InnerWorkings shares (ticker: INWK) have risen a radical 80%, with a recent print of 16.20.   But those reading the prospectus should also re-read the Dr. Seuss story about the Sneetches, who paid a huckster to change their plain bellies into star bellies, and vice versa. The chap ends up leaving town with all their money, while laughing: "They never will learn . . . You can't teach a Sneetch!"   You see, InnerWorkings goes to great lengths to obscure its ownership and control by a chap named Eric P. Lefkofsky who has a history of busting investors after promising to radically transform bricks-and-mortar industries. He seems to identify with Dr. Seuss's huckster: he called his last business Starbelly.com, a venture that rapidly went into bankruptcy and provoked fraud suits by investors alleging that Starbelly's software was never what Lefkofsky promised. The current InnerWorkings road show and stock-offering is, in part, aimed at cashing out much of Lefkofsky's stock while InnerWorkings shares teeter at stilted levels.   Eerily like Starbelly, there's less than meets the eye to the company's touted "PPM4" software, say some InnerWorkings ex-employees. In the weeks before Morgan Stanley's eagle-eyed due diligence team toured InnerWorkings for its August 2006 initial underwriting, workers stayed late padding the company's off-the-shelf FileMaker Pro database with an impressive-looking list of suppliers. Then they dummied up some screen-shots of the software for the inside cover of the prospectus. Citing the quiet period prior to its stock offering, the company declined to answer my questions.   Despite its Potemkin technology trappings, InnerWorkings is a glorified broker of print jobs. Like others of its ilk, it beats up on printers on behalf of corporate clients and splits any savings it extracts. Much of its sales growth has come through roll-up acquisitions of other print brokers. And a related-party transaction in the months before the IPO seems to have produced a big part of InnerWorkings' profits. Even so, the last-reported 12 months' profits amounted to a paltry $5.7 million. So the current stock market valuation of $700 million is 125-times those trailing profits.   That's a ridiculous valuation for a company in the mundane print brokerage business. And I suspect that fact isn't lost on the 37-year-old Lefkofsky who, with his wife and others, controls 35% of InnerWorkings shares via some holding companies. Unwilling to wait even until the Feb. 11 expiration of InnerWorkings's IPO lockup agreement, Lefkofsky and other insiders would unload 6.2 million shares in the follow-on offering that Morgan Stanley reportedly wants to price this week. That would net insiders $100 million.   InnerWorkings' prospectus makes only passing mention of Lefkofsky, with a sentence buried on page 54 describing him as someone "instrumental in the formation and development of our company" who served as a director until May 2006 and also as a consultant. When I asked InnerWorkings about him last week, a company spokesman said Lefkofsky's consulting had stopped back in June 2006.   So I thought it generous of Lefkofsky to be still laboring at InnerWorkings on Friday, while the firm's title-bearing leaders junketed on Morgan Stanley's road show. The InnerWorkings phone directory doesn't list Lefkofsky, but the company operator quickly put me through to his office, where a friendly-sounding lady told me he was running a meeting. He did not return repeated voice-mails and e-mails.   Ex-employees tell me that the company's disclosures hardly do justice to Lefkofsky's daily role at the company, where he has remained a foul-mouthed, coffee-chugging boss who micro-manages InnerWorkings by force of his strong personality and his group's 35% control position. On the other hand, it's easy to see why the company and its underwriters would want him to remain behind the curtain. He's left a trail of burned investors and fraud allegations. Just out of law school in 1994, Lefkofsky got the city of Columbus, Wisc., to back his takeover of a local clothing maker where he promised to create jobs making apparel branded by major-league sports teams. After laying off the workers, the firm sought bankruptcy protection, with its bankers alleging in a state suit that Lefkofsky applied the business's resources to starting his next venture, Starbelly.   Business-to-business procurement Websites were hot in 1999, and Starbelly.com held itself out as a marketplace where companies could arrange to put their logos on promotional items of clothing and hard goods like coffee mugs. Through some family connections, Lefkofsky and his partners attracted the eye of a Chicago-based promotional items vendor named Ha-Lo Industries. A due diligence investigation by Ernst & Young warned Ha-Lo that Starbelly's software was not as proprietary -- or even as functional -- as Starbelly claimed, according to Ha-Lo documents discovered in subsequent shareholder suits. The publicly-held Ha-Lo nevertheless bought Starbelly for $240 million in cash and stock in May 2000, saying that Starbelly's website would bring in $1 billion in revenues.   Lefkofsky and his Starbelly pals quickly assumed control of Ha-Lo, according to lawsuit records. But the software fizzled and the website was a flop. In scarcely a year, Ha-Lo wrote off Starbelly completely. It entered bankruptcy court in July 2001. Class action fraud suits against Lefkofsky and others were ultimately settled, but not before turning up vulgar, reckless Lefkofsky e-mails (one of which is reproduced verbatim below) that might bring shudders to any public investor entrusting her savings to his latest venture.   "Lets get funky. Lets announce everything. Lets be WILDLY positive in our forecasts," he told his Ha-Lo colleagues, even as that business was falling apart. "if we get wacked on the ride down --  who gives a sh*t. Is it going to worse than today? is our market cap going to fall to 200N, 100M who the f**k cares."   No wonder he's taken a low public profile since starting InnerWorkings with Richard A. Heise, Jr. -- another promoter hounded himself by the fraud suits of investors who said he never delivered his promised Internet software for managing executive benefit plans.   Numerous ex-employees of InnerWorkings told me that its vaunted software also doesn't work as claimed. A century ago, there was an investor named Mark Twain who lost a bundle investing in ersatz printing technologies. He said that history doesn't repeat itself, but sometimes it rhymes.   ---   For Barron's subscription information call 1-888-BARRONS ext. 685 or inquire online at http://www.barronsmag.com/subscription/subscription.html.     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  January 13, 2007 00:09 ET (05:09 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Headline: Barron's(1/15) Weekday Trader: Five Breakthrough Drugs For 2007
Story: (From BARRON'S)     By Johanna Bennett   They are: Novartis' diabetes drug, Galvus, and high-blood-pressure treatment, Tekturna; GlaxoSmithKline's breast-cancer drug, Tykerb; Wyeth's antidepressant,Pristiq; and Sanofi-Aventis' long overdue, much-anticipated diet product, Acomplia.   Overall, drug companies may launch two dozen major new products in 2007 that could generate annual sales of $30 billion in five to seven years, according to OrbiMed Advisors, a health-care investment firm.   That beats the 18 products launched last year with potential long-term yearly sales of $15 billion, and the nine products launched in 2005 with a sales potential of $8 billion, says OrbiMed.   "The pharmaceutical industry may have hit an inflection point in 2005, so now, there's a sense of optimism," says Trevor Polischuk, a portfolio manager at OrbiMed.   The details:   Galvus: Novartis' (ticker: NVS) diabetes drug, due to receive Food and Drug Administration approval next month, could generate a big splash.   Taken once a day, it is one of a new class of therapies that enhances the body's ability to lower elevated blood sugar. But it works without causing hypoglycemia or weight gain, common side-effects of older diabetes drugs.   Galvus got a rough start with the FDA. And Merck (MRK) launched a similar drug called Januvia in October 2006, setting the stage for a face-off. Still, U.S. sales of diabetes drugs total $8 billion. So Galvus has room to grab market share.   Sales could reach $232 million in 2007, according to Merrill Lynch. But in five to seven years, annual revenue should reach $2 billion, says OrbiMed.   Tekturna: Novartis faces less competition with Tekturna, a member of the first new class of high-blood-pressure medications launched in almost a decade.   The anti-hypertension market totals $40 billion a year. And Novartis already sports a top-selling product, Diovan.   But existing medications don't adequately control many patients' blood pressure. And Novartis believes that Tekturna, due for FDA approval in March, could reduce the damage that hypertension inflicts on the heart, kidneys and brain.   "The key to treating hypertension is preventing the complications, and if Tekturna does that, doctors can't justify not using it," says Jeremy Goldman, an analyst with Decision Resources, a market-research firm.   The FDA delayed approval last year in order to review additional data. And 2007 sales estimates look paltry -- $65 million to $80 million. But some analysts say peak annual sales could total $3 billion. "Novartis has to get out there and create a market," says Joseph Tooley, an analyst with A.G. Edwards & Sons.   Tykerb: GlaxoSmithKline's (GSK) Tykerb appears just as ground-breaking.   Like its rival Herceptin, Tykerb treats an aggressive form of breast cancer called Her2-positive. But it also marks the first cancer drug to fight the disease on two fronts, targeting two proteins that promote cancer-cell growth.   "It's a huge step forward," says Dr. Francis Arena, president of the Sass Foundation for Medical Research.   Out of the 1.5 million women battling breast cancer, 25% have excessive levels of a protein, Her2. Tykerb could get the green light in March as a treatment for advanced breast cancer, opening the door to sales of $200 million in 2007.   But GlaxoSmithKline is also testing the drug on early stages of the disease. In five years, annual sales could reach $1.2 billion, says Decision Resources.   Pristiq: Experts are divided on whether Wyeth's (WYE) new antidepressant, Pristiq, represents a significant medical advance.   If approved by the FDA later this month, it will face plenty of competition in the $20 billion depression-drug market. But in April, Pristiq could get the go-ahead for another use -- as the first nonhormonal treatment for the hot flashes and night sweats of menopause.   Cancer fears prevent many women from using hormone-replacement therapy. And aging Baby Boomers want better treatments.   "There could be a huge market for this drug," says Dr. Grant Mitchell, director of psychiatry at Northern Westchester Hospital. "There really aren't any great alternatives."   Barbara Ryan, an analyst with Deutsche Bank, predicts annual sales of $500 million by 2011. But OrbiMed says sales could hit $2 billion.   Acomplia: Acomplia was on a list of five promising drugs highlighted by Barron's Online last year ("Five New Drugs May Ease Pharma's Pain," Jan. 11, 2006). The others -- Sutent, Gardasil, Lucentis, and Exubera -- all received the green light.   Despite an ongoing delay in its debut, Acomplia holds promise. Already available in Europe, the Sanofi-Aventis (SNY) product not only helps patients lose weight, but improves cholesterol and blood-sugar levels, suggesting other possible uses.   Concerns have been raised about the possibility that the drug contributes to depression. So, rather than approving Acomplia last February, the FDA requested additional data. The agency could approve the drug by April, clearing the way for sales of $300 million in 2007.   And other uses, such as for treatment of diabetes, could drive annual sales to $2.8 billion by 2010, according to Banc of America Securities.     Of course, drug makers still face challenges that could damp their ability to launch these drugs.   A Democrat-controlled Congress could pass legislation toughening safety requirements for new drugs. And the industry's track record in launching products is spotty.   Problems launching any of these drugs would certainly wound their makers. But all five appear well on their way to FDA approval.   And if 2007 drug introductions exceed those of 2006, both patients and stock prices should see a healthier prognosis.   ---   For Barron's subscription information call 1-888-BARRONS ext. 685 or inquire online at http://www.barronsmag.com/subscription/subscription.html.     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  January 13, 2007 00:07 ET (05:07 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Headline: Barron's(1/15) 2007 Barron's Roundtable: Speaking -3-
Story: Cohen: Trade relationships depend on more than currency. Much relates to differentials in growth rates. For example, since 2000 Europe has grown at about a third of the pace of the U.S. That alone is a solid explanation for the growth of America's trade deficit with Europe.   Samberg: Where is the bubble? I'm confused. Marc appropriately gave us a history lesson about how the world has changed to one in which economic growth and personal freedom and better lifestyles are adoped across the globe. The most mature financial markets are here in the U.S., and we're the clearinghouse for the world, which can lead to long-term problems. But why turn a positive into a negative? The world is awash with growth. It is awash with liquidity, and our markets can clear liquidity better than any others.     Q: It is also awash in consumption, extravagance and debt.   Faber: America's current-account deficit has greased the whole world. Latin American markets are in the midst of a huge boom. The Argentine stock market is up 10 times from the lows. Latin American debt on a total-return basis has doubled in the past five years. In Asia we have bubbles in real estate. In the U.S. there's a debt bubble. Debt is now 330% of GDP. That will prevent the Fed from ever pursuing tight monetary policies, even if it becomes necessary.   Hickey: Asset bubbles are always fun while you are going through it. The tulip bubble was fun. The Mississippi bubble was fun. But they always end in tears and disaster.   Gabelli: I'll float a bubble. Abby, the Democrats won the midterm elections in a landslide. Marc, should we worry about a politically motivated constraint on global trade?   Faber: I'm less worried about that than this: The five brokerage firms in New York -- Merrill Lynch, Morgan Stanley, Lehman Brothers, Bear Stearns and Goldman Sachs -- paid out $36 billion in 2006 bonuses. Compensation and bonuses together roughly are equal to Vietnam's GDP. I see a bipolar word in which there's the typical household in the U.S. or Western Europe, and then this huge wealth concentration. It will lead to a political backlash one day.     Q: Starting in Connecticut.   Cohen: I don't believe there is going to be a significant change in the next couple of years. The Democrats took control of the House. They have a razor-thin margin in the Senate, and they are posturing and preparing for the next presidential election. In terms of economic policy, they'll do things that won't face much resistance and will look good for the '08 election, like raising the minimum wage. With regard to protectionism, I don't hear people talking about restrictions on imports. American consumers benefit from them. The real discussion will focus on making sure markets in Europe and Asia are open to U.S. goods and services.   Schafer: One bubble in the making is the private-equity market. Buyers took four of our companies last year, which is fine. But there is so much money being thrown at companies. Henry McVey at Morgan Stanley has talked about the fact that company managements are not being paid to take    risks. They are being paid to have more cash on the balance sheet. There is too much cash on corporate balance sheets. One reason the market will be buoyed is because LBOs [leveraged buyouts] will continue in 2007. When and how it ends I don't know, but it may not be pretty.   In the meantime, investment banks are being asked by companies to examine strategic alternatives. After sending a team to spend time with management for six months, they decide the best alternative is to go private, with the bank participating in the deal. But the company's board says "that's a potential conflict of interest, let's have an open auction." For only one month, other people try to get the information the investment banker had for six months. There is a conflict of interest on the part of investment bankers.   Gabelli: The bigger conflict is that management knows the company and is stealing it from shareholders. The management buyout is the ultimate form of acting on inside information.   Samberg: In 1982 cash and marketable securities were 12% of the assets of the typical American corporation. Now they are 24%. You buy a company with a very liquid balance sheet and leverage it up. That's how you get the excess returns. These liquidity things are so intact that the market is going to be up 10% this year.     Q: Meryl, what have you got to say?   Witmer: A lot of private-equity firms are selling to one another, which raises my eyebrows. Of course, sometimes it's justified when the buyer has a business insight or the timing is right and they cash out. As for the stock market, I don't think it's particularly overvalued, but I don't see a lot of appreciation this year. We run stocks through our model, and most come out valued at the right price.     Q: You ought to take a year's vacation   Witmer: A lot can happen in a year. If there's a downdraft, I might find something good. It only takes a few stocks to have a good year. But it is tough to find really good, cheap stocks, especially in the U.S.   Zulauf: Going back to buyouts, at the last peak, in the late 1990s, buyers paid an average of nine times Ebitda [earnings before interest, taxes, depreciation and amortization]. Now they're paying slightly below six times, and interest rates are much lower. The process will continue, which will help to support the stock market.     Q: It doesn't hurt that the Fed has been so expansive.   Zulauf: The world is expansive. Monetary policy will probably remain expansive, leading to an investment mania in coming years.     Q: Scott, want to say something?   Black: We recognize the senior senator from Thailand. You've got five minutes. I'm on the right tail of the normal distribution curve this year. I'm mildly optimistic about the U.S. economy and the stock market. The economy is much more resilient, year in and year out, than people give it credit for. We've had structural deficits since Reagan took office. The accumulated national debt has gone from $1 trillion to $8.7 trillion, and somehow the stock market continues to go up. Notwithstanding Fred Hickey and the debacle in housing, real GDP grew at 2% in the latest quarter, while core CPI is down to 2.2%.   In the first four or five months of the year, inflation will abate. [Fed Chairman Ben] Bernanke's threshold is 2%; he's striking a delicate balance between core inflation and recession, and he will opt not to be the first Fed chairman in a while to cause a recession. Core inflation will drop below 2%, and the Fed will cut rates to 5% in either March or May. I wouldn't be surprised to see a 43/4% fed- funds rate by the end of the year.     Q: What do you see for the stock market?   Black: Nominal S&P 500 earnings will grow 6.5%. Friday [Jan. 5] the S&P closed at 1409.71. We have $86.70 in '07 earnings, so the index sells for 16.2 times forward earnings. By historical standards, from 1946 on, it's in the comfort zone between 16 and 17 times earnings. The market is fairly priced. Based on my dividend-discount model, using a 6 1/2% growth rate on dividends, I've got S&P dividends of $27.35 at the end of the year. This implies the market could be up about 8 1/2% year-over-year.   Witmer: That's not a bad year.   Black: It is good year considering the market has been at an all-time high. Let's go back to deals, deals, deals, as Mario likes to say. Last year there were $3.79 trillion of mergers and acquisitions. Private-equity buyers took out $660 billion of stock. You have a shrinking supply of equities, a shrinking float. A lot of money is moving from traditional money managers such as myself into the private-equity world. There's an impetus to put that money to work. It's not going to be a blowout year, but a better one than most people think.   Faber: The supply of stock in the U.S. shrunk by 5% last year. There was one big seller: the individual investor. One portion of the economy -- the asset shufflers -- is ultra-liquid. But the individual is illiquid. Individuals have to sell stock because home prices aren't going up any more.   Cohen: The flow-of-funds data suggest something different. Home prices stopped rising about 12 to 18 months ago and mutual-fund inflows began to improve, which says something about the incremental dollar. I'm not talking about expenditures on primary residences, but people who might have been contemplating a second home no longer necessarily view that as a good investment. They are now looking more actively at financial assets.     Q: John, what is your take on the new year?   Neff: I'm in the Goldilocks school.   Samberg: That school has a very big class.   Neff: I see the economy up maybe 2 1/2%, moderate wage-benefit increases, some price increases, some decline in commodity costs -- oil, principally. Copper and some of the other ones are starting to take a lacing, too. That nets out to about an 8% to 10% earnings increase. If you buy that, the market trades for about 15.4 times the new year's earnings, which is not exactly a giveaway. But it's reasonable relative to the alternatives. I've got the market going up 8% to 10%, plus a 2% yield. The consumer is not overextended, in my view.   You don't get out of enough.   Neff: Consumers are biding their time. Sooner or later, the department stores or Detroit start to give stuff away. There is a disservice being done in the way the savings rate is calculated. It was minus 1% in November, meaning the consumer spent 1% more than he had coming in. But that calculation does not include any appreciation in what you already own, like your home or your stock portfolio. Some homes are down in value, but it's a local market.   Hickey: Every area is down!   Faber: But Park Avenue is up!   (MORE TO FOLLOW) Dow Jones Newswires  January 13, 2007 00:03 ET (05:03 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Headline: Barron's(1/15) We've Got The Goods
Story: (From BARRON'S)     By Andrew Bary   Rather than simply compare the performance of the stocks that we write about to the Standard & Poor's 500, the large-stock benchmark, we use the S&P MidCap 400 for mid-sized companies and the Russell 2000 for small outfits. We employ the S&P 500 as a comparison for large U.S. stocks and all foreign stocks. These three indexes were up 9% to 17% last year. (Note that the ups and downs of stocks we profile can't be directly compared with the annual showings of these indexes,since we're measuring performance from 52 publication dates.)   We began this scorecard three years ago, to keep readers up to date on the performance of the stocks we write about. We're now doing two scorecards each year -- an annual tally in January and a mid-year update in July.   Barron's isn't an investment newsletter, and stock-picking isn't our only measure of our performance. We aim to write insightful and engaging articles on a wide array of investment-related topics, but we do recognize that many readers come to the publication for stock-picking ideas.   Our 2005 picks are also worth a look, since their average 18 months' seasoning may give a finer gauge of our stock-picking skills. Through the end of 2006, the 2005 bullish group -- 104 stocks -- was up an average of 23.4%, versus a gain 18.8% for the benchmarks. Details of this tally will be available on the free portion of Barron's Online (www.barrons.com).   Since we began the scorecard, our bullish picks have beaten the market every year. The 2004 crop was up 27.5% through the end of 2005, double the 13.7% rise in the benchmarks. The 2003 group was strong through the end of 2004, gaining 53.8%, versus 34.7% for the benchmarks.     Talk to most investment managers, and they'll say that short-selling is a lot harder than investing from the long side for various reasons, including overcrowding in popular short positions and the market's upward bias.   We've certainly had more trouble identifying overvalued stocks than undervalued ones. Our 2004 and 2005 bearish stock picks were up more than the benchmarks.   Credit luck or skill, but we finally had a good year on the short side in 2006. The 32 bearish picks fell an average of 3.2% through year-end, versus the benchmarks' 6.7% rise. While most readers don't short stocks, bearish stories may help warn readers away from overpriced or overhyped stocks, or possible financial chicanery.   The '05 group of bearish stock selections didn't do as well as last year's. They rose 23.6% through the end of 2006, versus a gain of 20.6% for the benchmark indexes.   The calculations here don't include our industry or market stories, which often mention multiple stocks. Our results last year would be even better if we did -- because we've had several winning industry profiles, like our controversially upbeat story on housing-related shares ("Big Ripple," Aug. 28). Many readers said they thought we were too early in recommending housing stocks, because the industry downturn had just begun. The stocks, however, were discounting a disastrous outlook, and we caught them near their summer trough. A bullish cover story on the airlines industry ("Airlines Are Flying," Oct. 2) also proved to be well-timed.   Among last year's bullish picks, some notable winners were Apple Computer (ticker: AAPL), Mastercard (MA), Coach (COH), Goodyear (GT), McGraw-Hill (MHP), IAC/Interactive (IACI), Hewlett-Packard (HPQ) and Goldman Sachs (GS). Apple and Goodyear have continued to advance in 2007, with Apple surging to a record last week amid hopes for its iPhone.   We ranked the stocks based on performance, making it easy to see where we got things right and wrong. The tally shows how each did through year-end, and how the benchmark index did over the same span. We weight every stock equally in calculating the scorecard, even though some may quibble that this approach gives an outsized weighting to smaller companies.   Certain bullish calls from 2006 haven't panned out, including Yahoo! (YHOO), Newmont Mining (NEM), Eli Lilly (LLY), Micron Technology (MU) and XM Satellite Radio (XMSR). In a cover story about the satellite-radio industry ("Don't Bet on Howard," Jan. 23), we argued that Howard Stern's employer, Sirius Satellite Radio, was overpriced and that XM was a better bet. Both were bad choices. Sirius fell 43.8% through year-end, while XM slid 47.8%. Yet XM has rallied 15% in 2007, boosted by hope of a merger between the two satellite-radio outfits.   One of our bearish profiles that worked as advertised was Pegasus Wireless (PGSW), a troubled cellphone operator whose stock plunged and was delisted from Nasdaq. We were skeptical on Sulphco's (SUF) claims it has ultrasound technology that can turn heavy grades of crude oil into more valuable, sweeter crude. The company has done little to commercialize its product, and its president quit late last year.   We didn't buy the hype about Vonage (VG), the money-losing Internet telecom provider, whose stock is off sharply since its May IPO.   Yet we erred in our skepticism over NYSE Group (NYS), parent of the New York Stock Exchange, which surged after merging with Archipelago in March. Doubting Google (GOOG) in February 2006 was a bad move. Finally, it was a bad bet to buck the casino industry: Station Casinos (STN), which looked richly priced last summer, received a premium-priced buyout offer in December.   ---   For Barron's subscription information call 1-888-BARRONS ext. 685 or inquire online at http://www.barronsmag.com/subscription/subscription.html.     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  January 13, 2007 00:09 ET (05:09 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Headline: Barron's(1/15) Follow-Up: A Bright Outlook At Xerox
Story: (From BARRON'S)     By Sandra Ward   Investors have done well by Xerox since we ran a bullish piece eight months ago ("Warming up the Copier," May 1, 2006). The shares are up 21.2%, the company's debt has been upgraded to investment grade, cash-flow growth is strong and the company's been buying back stock and keeping costs down.   At 17.01 a share, there's still room for price appreciation in the shares of the Stamford, Conn.-based document-management and services company.   That's why Harris Associates and some of its Oakmark family of mutual funds are sticking with it, according to James Benson, partner and securities analyst. He cites the continued progress Xerox is making in realigning its business mix to emphasize high-end digital color printing and de-emphasize the lower-margin, old-line "light lens" technology. Xerox also remains undervalued based on its cash-flow generation, he says.   Ditto, says Eric Heyman of the Olstein Financial Alert Fund. He sees the stock climbing possibly to 20 to 22 a share in the next year to 18 months.   At its annual analyst day in November, Xerox reiterated it expects to post earnings of between 34 cents and 37 cents for the fourth quarter, compared with 27 cents a year earlier. But, for the full-year 2007, the company tempered its outlook and suggested earnings would come in between $1.12 and $1.16 a share; the current Street expectation is $1.15.   Sales of its new Nuvera line, a high-end black-and-white print-production system, continue to lag. Another headwind: The move away from its light-lens technology is also taking longer than expected. In lowering its guidance, Xerox management, aware of new product competition for its color systems and concerned about a shifting economic climate, was also taking a prudent approach.   Benson of Harris Associates isn't too concerned about a slowdown. Economic activity in the U.S. remains solid, he says, and Western Europe is picking up. Brazil is also showing good growth. He notes, too, that Xerox customers are well represented among Fortune 1,000 companies, which are enjoying strong profitability, have lots of cash on their balance sheets and are in a position to spend to improve their businesses.   Xerox is also attracting notice on a different front. Speculation swirled last Monday, based on options activity, that Eastman Kodak (ticker: EK) was interested in making a bid for Xerox. Although the notion of struggling and much-smaller Kodak possibly acquiring Xerox was dismissed as unlikely, many pointed out that Xerox's business characteristics could potentially appeal to a cash-rich private-equity group on the prowl.   ---   For Barron's subscription information call 1-888-BARRONS ext. 685 or inquire online at http://www.barronsmag.com/subscription/subscription.html.     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  January 13, 2007 00:08 ET (05:08 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Headline: Venezuela Pres: Central Bank To Surrender $8.37B To Govt
Story: CARACAS (Dow Jones)--Venezuela's central bank will surrender $8.37 billion of its foreign reserve holdings to a development fund, a higher contribution than originally estimated, Venezuela's president announced Saturday.   "The central bank will have to turn over $8.37 billion to the Fonden development fund soon," Chavez said during his yearly address to congress. "Foreign reserve holdings belong to the country not to the central bank."   Chavez called on the bank to turn over the money quickly. "When are we getting that money?" he asked Planning Minister Jorge Giordani during his address. "Soon, I hope."   A few days ago, the president had said the bank would transfer $7 billion to the fund controlled by him and his top ministers. The Fonden, which receives money from the central bank and state oil company Petroleos de Venezuela (PVZ.YY), or PdVSA, now holds $18.7 billion in its coffers, the president noted.   Chavez recently announced he would replace outgoing central bank directors and would scrap any mention of central bank independence from the constitution, putting an end to the bank's autonomy.     -By Raul Gallegos, Dow Jones Newswires; 58-212-564-1339; raul.gallegos@dowjones.com     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  January 13, 2007 12:25 ET (17:25 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Headline: Barron's(1/15) For TV Broadcasters, Picture Is Improving
Story: (From BARRON'S)     By Andrew Bary   The broadcast television business has been viewed warily by many investors because of a fragmenting TV audience, a shift in ad dollars to the Internet from traditional media and the growing use of Tivo-type recorders that let viewers skip commercials.   Shares of the owners of TV stations, which carry CBS, NBC, ABC, Fox and other network programming, generally have declined in recent years. But Wall Street is warming toward the group amid optimism that TV operators will be able to secure retransmission fees from cable operators and that the business will prove more durable than newspapers, thanks in part to the popularity of local news broadcasts. The publicly traded TV operators generally own stations in mid-sized to small cities, which aren't as threatened by the Internet as big-market stations.   There could be more upside this year in the low-profile TV group, which includes Hearst-Argyle Television (ticker: HTV), Sinclair Broadcast (SBGI), Lin TV (TVL), Gray Television (GTN) and Nexstar Broadcasting (NXST), if Sinclair is successful in its current battle with Mediacom Communications (MCCC) to be paid for providing local stations to Mediacom cable systems. Sinclair has pulled its stations from Mediacom in a bid to force the cable operator to cave in.   Cable operators historically have paid little or nothing for local network TV stations, while anteing up for cable networks like Walt Disney's (DIS) ESPN, which receives about $2 a month per cable subscriber. Major satellite TV providers generally pay for local stations.   The broadcasters have a big ally in CBS (CBS), which owns 39 stations and is eager to be paid by cable operators. Its CEO, Les Moonves, said at an investor conference last week that he's "optimistic that we will get paid for our content," with significant revenue likely by 2009. Moonves said "every nickel" in retransmission fees "goes right to the bottom line." If the broadcasters win the retransmission battle, it could boost annual cash flow 15% to 25%. CBS might get 50 cents per cable subscriber by 2009.   Another big plus was the recent sale by The New York Times (NYT) of a group of TV stations to Oak Hill Capital Partners, a private-equity group, for $575 million -- about $150 million more than some on the Street had expected. Oak Hill paid a stiff 13 times projected 2006 pre-tax cash flow, or earnings before interest, taxes, depreciation and amortization, for mediocre stations.   This suggests that private equity still has a strong appetite for TV stations, which could put a floor under television-station stocks. As the table shows, the Times got a price that comfortably exceeds the current valuation of the public broadcasters, which are valued at 8 to 11 times projected 2006 pre-tax cash flow. (See accompanying illustration -- Barron's January 15.) Three of the operators, Gray, Lin and Nexstar, have considerable debt, which increases risk -- and opportunity. Gray, Lin and Nexstar effectively offers return characteristics of leveraged buyouts, without paying a big fee to an LBO operator.   And, contrary to popular perception, broadcast TV is gaining viewers this season, at the expense of cable.   "Wall Street has sold our industry short," says Bob Prather, president of Atlanta-based Gray Television. "Our stock is way undervalued. I've been preaching the gospel, but not many people seem to believe me." Gray insiders evidently do, because they were buying last month.   Gray focuses on TV stations in university towns and state capitals like Tallahasee, Fla., that have strong growth. Of Gray's 36 stations, 24 lead their markets in ratings. Prather says Gray doesn't want to sell out, but "if the price is right, we'd take a hard look at it." Gray, Sinclair, Lin and Nexstar have market values under $1 billion, making them bite-sized acquisition candidates.   Irving, Texas-based Nexstar gets about 16 cents a month per cable subscriber after winning a battle with cable operators in 2006. "We were the pioneer in taking on the cable companies," says Matthew Devine, Nexstar's chief financial officer. "We service our local communities with as much as six hours of news a day." Devine is thrilled that CBS will take on the cable guys. "The retransmission fees will only grow as we draft behind the big dogs."   Given Nexstar's low cash-flow valuation, the stock has plenty of appreciation potential. One bullish investor says the stock could double from its current price of $5 if it gets only a modestly higher valuation or keeps paying down debt.   Hearst-Argyle, largest of the five broadcasters, is the sector's blue chip. Its top shareholder, the privately held Hearst media conglomerate, keeps buying stock in the open market. Hearst owns 74% of the 92 million outstanding shares, which trade around 26. Ultimately, it could buy out the public holders. And Lin TV might get a buyout offer from Hicks, Muse, which owns almost half its stock.   ---   For Barron's subscription information call 1-888-BARRONS ext. 685 or inquire online at http://www.barronsmag.com/subscription/subscription.html.     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  January 13, 2007 00:09 ET (05:09 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Headline: WSJ(1/13) Skype Duo Envisions Merging Best Of TV, Web
Story: (From THE WALL STREET JOURNAL)     By Kevin J. Delaney   Janus Friis and Niklas Zennstrom roiled the music industry with their first venture and the telecom world with their next. Now, the Scandinavian entrepreneurs behind the KaZaA file-sharing software and Skype Internet calling are backing an online video start-up that could shake up the television and cable industries as well.   Their closely held venture, which goes by the code name "The Venice Project," promises to let users watch professional video such as TV shows and movies whenever they want on their personal computers with better image quality than many popular video sites. The free offering combines elements of traditional TV, such as channels that users can flip between, with Web functions such as chatting between users and keyword search for programs that consumers can then pull up on demand.   "We want to merge the best of TV with the best of the Internet," says Mr. Friis. The Venice Project's chief executive, Fredrik de Wahl, says its aspirations are grand: "We're going after TV-like audiences on the Web."   Like TV, the service will be financed by advertising that will be shared with the video-content owners.   A small number of users have been testing the service since last month, with a broad public release planned for the first half of this year. The Venice Project arrives in the wake of an explosion in Internet video consumption, with research firm eMarketer Inc. estimating that 123 million Americans will view such video at least once a month this year. But it also follows the emergence of countless other online video options for consumers, ranging from Google Inc.'s leading YouTube service to Apple Inc.'s popular online store for downloading TV shows and movies for a fee.   "What they're doing is incredibly cool, says Mike Homer, chief executive of nonprofit Internet-video service Open Media Network and co-founder of online video company Kontiki Inc., which was purchased by VeriSign Inc. last year. But "there's just a lot of stuff going on in the industry now that makes what they're doing not so unique."   Mr. Friis says the Venice Project isn't late, because it goes further in combining aspects of the Web and TV than any existing offering. Whereas YouTube and other popular sites offer short, low-video-quality clips -- most uploaded by individual users -- the Venice Project plans to offer full TV shows and movies from commercial content owners. Mr. de Wahl says it won't let consumers submit clips until quality and copyright issues are resolved.   He says the video is broadcast quality or better. Clips in its current test generally look good viewed full-screen on a PC monitor, but they often stutter, and parts of the images appear as small colored squares rather than the smooth image of a DVD.   Company executives concede that getting permission for users to watch high-quality, popular content is crucial. They'll only disclose that National Geographic, Warner Music Group Corp. and the IndyCar Series are providing video, but test users see content from other partners. "It's very significant in that it really is a medium that allows content owners to distribute unlimited amount of content and then format it in all kinds of different ways," says Alex Zubillaga, Warner Music's executive vice president for digital strategy and business development.   In addition to trying to reinvent TV, the Venice Project aims to reshape TV commercials by drawing from what works on the Internet. It says advertisers will be able to target their ads, which combine full-screen video commercials with interactive features, based on users' video viewing habits and other data such as the user's location. Wrigley Co., Deutsche Telekom AG's T-Mobile USA and L'Oreal SA's Maybelline brand are among those participating in the current test.   The Venice Project uses so-called peer-to-peer technology -- which relies on users' computers to store and transmit data to each other -- that is similar to KaZaA and other file-swapping networks. But the company only streams the video, rather than letting users download whole program files, and says that it uses technology to prevent individuals from reassembling any data stored on their hard drives as watchable video. The Venice Project also serves some video from its own computers in order to increase reliability.   While Messrs. Friis and Zennstrom are the Venice Project's co-founders and remain involved, they still work full-time at Skype, which was purchased by eBay Inc. for $2.6 billion in 2005.     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  January 13, 2007 00:00 ET (05:00 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Headline: Barron's(1/15) 2007 Barron's Roundtable: Speaking -2-
Story: Gabelli: I'm in Dear Abby's camp on the economy. In the first half, comparisons with last year will get more sluggish because of inventory corrections. That smoothes out incrementally going into the second half. Other ele- ments -- exports, nonresidential construction, consumer wages, employment, the wealth effect at the upper end -- provide ballast for the balance of '07. Inflation is a different issue. Profit margins will erode. You'll see more profit warnings. But earnings in general will be OK. About 40% of S&P 500 earnings are non- U.S.-based. U.S. companies operating outside the U.S. will do well, and currency translation will help, with the euro at <euro>1.30. But I'm with Felix on the stock market.     Q: How so?   Gabelli: The market hasn't had a 10% decline in a long time, and it's going to happen, whether in the middle of March or the middle of October. By the end of the year the market will be unchanged or slightly up, and '08 will look good.     Q: You've been quiet, Marc. What's wrong?   Faber: Whereas Felix only agrees with Abby, I agree with all of you. I agree with Art that we are in the midst of the greatest synchronized economic expansion in the world. In the first 150 years of capitalism, the colonial system prevailed. It was never the objective of the industrialized countries to boost growth rates in the colonies. They were used for exploitation. Once the colonial system broke down, roughly three billion people fell under communism and socialism. After 1980 commodity prices collapsed and Latin America went into a depression. Then the Soviet Union collapsed. While Latin America began to recover in the 1990s, Japan, at that time the second-largest economy in the world, had stopped growing. The Asian crisis hit in '97, the Russian crisis in '98. So there was no synchronized growth.   The recovery began in November 2001 in the U.S. Strong consumption growth in the U.S. boosted industrial production, notably in China. Incremental industrial growth, combined with strong personal-income gains and capital spending, then led China to import resources, in particular oil. That led to rising commodities prices, which greased the economies of the Middle East and the former Soviet Union. Demand from China for copper and iron ore greased Latin America and Australia, and those countries grew rapidly. They demanded more imported goods, capital goods and luxury goods from Europe and Japan, and bingo! You suddenly had the whole world expanding rapidly. However . . .     Q: We knew that was coming.   Faber: I agree with Art. I just disagree with his conclusions. Global imbalances have increased. The emerging world has grown much more rapidly than the United States. In the U.S., ultra-expansionary monetary policy got under way ahead of Y2K in 1999. It continued after 2001, when the Fed slashed interest rates to 1% from 6.5%. Though the Fed has raised rates since 2004, to 5.25%, we still have expansionary monetary policies worldwide. If you define economic growth by consumption, the U.S. has grown rapidly and will probably continue to grow. If you print money you give people the opportunity to spend. But along with the spending came a growing trade and current-account deficit, which was offset by surpluses in Asia. Every region of the world has a current-account surplus with the U.S. For the first time in capitalism, the poor countries, notably China, are financing consumption in the U.S. This will not last forever.   In 2006 -- hurrah, hurrah -- the Dow Jones Industrial Average was up 16% and the S&P 500 14%. But in euro terms the S&P was up less than 5%. In gold terms it was down. Against most commodities, the Dow was down. The U.S. also has a split economy. The typical household is not doing well. But one economy is doing exceedingly well: the asset shufflers in this room. [Nervous laughter] This economy is in the greatest bubble ever. There's a bubble in the art market; art prices were up 27% last year. There's a bubble in equities, especially in emerging markets, and in real estate in Anglo-Saxon countries. The big threat is not that liquidity will vanish because of Federal Reserve action. The Fed will print money, I guarantee you. But when asset markets go up, they create liquidity by allowing people to borrow more money against appreciating assets. When asset values go down, liquidity contracts immediately because people repay loans. The moment the asset bubble begins to deflate, liquidity will contract.     Q: Housing assets are deflating, and there's no liquidity crisis.   Faber: Housing could fall in real terms for the next 10 years, but stay level or rise in nominal terms. It depends how much money you print. By the way, I have here a million-dollar bill. In my lifetime I will need a million dollars to buy a cup of coffee.     Q: How long do you plan to live?   Faber: I am already on bonus time.   Cohen: The single largest buyer of U.S. Treasuries outside the U.S. has been oil-producing nations, via their investment offices in London, over the last two years. If oil prices stabilize at today's levels or continue to fall, the Treasury market could be affected. One potential area of vulnerability could be the U.S. bond market, including corporate bonds, about 30% of which are owned by foreigners. There could be a widening of yield spreads, which are at historical lows now.   Gross: Abby has hit the nail on the head. In the U.S., housing has not done well in the past six months, but other assets have. Liquidity has been provided on a global basis not only by the petroleum-reserve nations, but by Asian exporters with surplus reserves. Combined, Asian countries accumulate about $400 billion of excess reserves per year. OPEC-related nations have $500 billion. That's almost $1 trillion a year of surplus monies that, in a sense, have been oversaved and underspent. They have been flowing into global asset markets via higher commodity and stock prices. They have come back in the form of subsidized yields not only in the Treasury market but in corporate bonds. They've come back in almost all risky-asset markets.   Central banks now are raising rates and constricting liquidity. If oil, which has fallen from $72 a barrel in August/September to the high-$50s, stays at current levels, that, too, represents a contraction in liquidity, perhaps of $200 billion to $300 billion. If levered up -- and it has been levered in all these markets -- it represents a contraction of perhaps $1 trillion.     Q: What happened to the cliche that falling oil prices are a tax cut for the consumer?   Gross: They are a tax cut in terms of expenditures, but higher oil prices also have been stimulative in the past 12 to 24 months. OPEC has spent the money in the asset markets, exerting a multiplier effect in terms of wealth creation.   Faber: Bill is correct to talk about an excess of liquidity, but I disagree about its cause. America's current-account deficit has led to surpluses elsewhere. In China, the trade and the current-account surpluses have expanded in the past two years. To bring the imbalances into order -- to reduce the current-account deficit -- you need a significant recession in the United States. In other words, consumption must go down. Otherwise there is no chance in a million years that the U.S. deficits will shrink.   Cohen: Be careful what you wish for. A weaker U.S. economy would have a dramatic impact on economic activity outside the U.S. If the United States is the ultimate end-user, all of Asia, China included, would suffer.   Faber: The U.S. overestimates its importance in the global economy today. It might have been true in the 1960s and '70s that when the U.S. sneezed, the world caught a cold. But in Asia today, we have an economic bloc that is far bigger than the U.S. or Europe. There are 3.6 billion consumers. Also, 56% of U.S. imports from China represent goods made by subsidiaries of American companies. If you run a company and there's a demand deficiency, which production would you maintain: the high-cost or low-cost producer? In the next U.S. recession, there will be even more outsourcing.   Zulauf: If the U.S. enters a recession, the world will be affected by the shrinking of trade surpluses elsewhere and the multiplier effect.     Q: Archie, what do you think?   MacAllaster: We've had five good years and the stock market is due for a correction. There appears to be way too much leverage. Margin accounts are sky-high, about as high as they have ever been. Even though you can find a lot of reasonably priced stocks -- I can, in my kinds of stocks -- it is likely the market will have a good selloff at some point. With 2 1/2% growth in the economy for the year, the market will do a little better in the second half. But it will close just about where it is now. If I had to pick one or the other, I'd say lower.   I want to re-emphasize that margin debt is way, way up. You know, sometimes the borrowing is 10 times the equity provided. At some point, all these private-equity investors and others can't be geniuses. Some will do well -- the old 10% -- but some won't, and that could become a real problem for the economy and the market.   Faber: Let's talk about China's currency. The Chinese pegged the yuan at 8.28 to the dollar in 1994. The peg held until 2005, when they let the currency float upward. Now it's around CNY7.80 to the dollar. In the long run, the yuan and other Asian currencies will appreciate against the dollar. But it won't make a difference to the U.S. trade deficit because the Chinese import resources and components. They will buy these resources with a stronger currency, process them and send them to the U.S. The Chinese will maintain a trade surplus for a very long time, and their currency could double in value.   A strong currency makes you strong, a weak currency makes you weak. If the U.S. opts for a weak currency, as Abby says, it should be careful what it has wished for. A weak dollar could lift inflation rates substantially and potentially lead to a breakdown of the U.S. bond market.   (MORE TO FOLLOW) Dow Jones Newswires  January 13, 2007 00:03 ET (05:03 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Headline: CdP Must Sell 10.2% Of Enel To Buy Terna -Italy Top Court
Story: ROME (Dow Jones)--State-run lender Cassa Depositi e Prestiti, or CdP, must sell its 10.2% stake in power company Enel SpA (EN) if it wants to purchase a 30% stake in grid company Terna SpA (TRN.MI), Italy's top administrative court ruled late Friday.   The Consiglio di Stato upheld a decision by a regional court last year, which had ruled in favor of a 2005 decision by Italy's antitrust regulator that CdP can't have the power to influence the strategy of both the nation's biggest power company and its national grid.   According to the regional court ruling, CdP must sell the Enel shares, worth nearly EUR5.0 billion, between July 2007 and July 2009 if it wants to go ahead with the Terna purchase.   CdP, which is controlled by the Italian finance ministry, said in a statement that it would discuss what decision to take at one of its upcoming board meetings.   Italy's finance ministry controls Enel with a 20% direct stake and the 10.2% indirect stake held by CdP. Finance Minister Tommaso Padoa-Schioppa last year said he didn't want to cut the government's stake in the former power monopoly below 30% to avoid making Enel an easier takeover target.   According to Italian rules, an investor must launch a full takeover bid for a company and therefore spend more money if it buys a stake of more than 30%.     -By Luca Di Leo, Dow Jones Newswires; +39 335 6171960; luca.dileo@dowjones.com     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  January 13, 2007 09:41 ET (14:41 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Headline: Barron's(1/15) Speaking Of Divs: Payouts Defy Gravity
Story: (From BARRON'S)     By Shirley A. Lazo   The 65 component stocks that populate the Dow Jones averages continued to lift their dividend payouts in the fourth quarter. The action was comprised entirely of dividend enrichments -- there wasn't a payout cut or omission to be seen.   In his latest survey of the Dow stocks, Barron's statistics manager Peter Miller counted four payout boosts among the 30 Industrials: Altria Group (ticker: MO); Home Depot (HD); McDonald's (MCD) and Microsoft (MSFT). All but the Home Depot hike, however, had been declared in the third quarter. Embattled Home Depot, by the way, added to its payout twice in 2006.   Another six Industrials sweetened their dividends, too, though these are payable in 2007's first quarter. That group: AT&T (T); Boeing (BA); Walt Disney (DIS); General Electric (GE); Intel (INTC) and Pfizer (PFE).   The 20 Transportation issues contributed two boosts -- by C.H. Robinson Worldwide (CHRW) and Burlington Northern Santa Fe (BNI). Robinson's is payable this quarter, and Burlington Northern's had been declared in the September quarter.   Among the 15 Utilities, American Electric Power raised its payout in the quarter. Four more enhanced October-December dividends by Edison International (EIX); Exelon (EXC); FirstEnergy (FE) and TXU (TXU) have their payout dates this quarter.   Besides these blue chips, the following 14 DJIA companies increased their dividends in 2006: American Express (AXP); American International Group (AIG); Caterpillar (CAT); Citigroup (C); Coca-Cola (KO); ExxonMobil (XOM); Honeywell (HON); International Business Machines (IBM); Johnson & Johnson (JNJ); Procter & Gamble (PG); 3M (MMM); United Technologies (UTX); Verizon (VZ) and Wal-Mart (WMT).   General Motors (GM) had the only dividend cut among all the Dow stocks last year.   Barron's Miller calculated that the combined Industrials paid out $267.75 in 2006 dividends, 8.5% above 2005's $246.85, for a 2.2% yield.   There were 11 other dividend hikes in 2006 among the 20 DJTA stocks via Alexander & Baldwin (ALEX); CSX (CSX); Expeditors International (EXPD); FedEx (FDX); GATX (GMT); J.B. Hunt Transport (JHBT); Landstar System (LSTR); Norfolk Southern (NSC); Overseas Shipholding (OSG); Ryder System (R) and United Parcel Service (UPS).   CSX and Expeditors also did 2-for-1 stock splits.   The total payout by the Transports in 2006, according to Miller, surged 20.1%, to $47.56 from 2005's $39.60. Yield: 1%.   The 15 Dow Utilities disbursed $14.31, versus $13.10, which made for a 3% yield. Other powered-up payouts came from CenterPoint Energy (CNP); Consolidated Edison (ED); Dominion Resources (D); Duke Energy (DUK); PG&E (PCG); Public Service Enterprise Group (PEG); Southern Co. (SO) and Williams Cos. (WMB).   To gauge their full return, here's how much each Dow groups' stock prices rose in 2006: Industrials, 16.3%, Transports, 8.7%, and Utilities, 12.8%.     Tough competition, rising costs and a drop in foot traffic are giving the casual-dining industry indigestion these days. One leading chain, Ruby Tuesday (RI), for example, posted a 4% drop in fiscal second-quarter (ended Nov. 30) profits, although revenue grew 14%. Given the environment, chief executive and founder Samuel E. (Sandy) Beall III said the Tennessee company had "performed well on earnings and made solid progress on plans to take the brand toward a high- quality casual-dining restaurant."   In a show of confidence, Ruby Tuesday last week announced its intention to boost its semiannual dividend (25 cents, after being hiked in July from 2.25 cents). The increase will be done annually, following the end of its fiscal year (May 31), in line with its percentage increase in net income, up to 10%. Also, it added five million shares to the remaining 5.2 million in its stock-buyback program.   The Big Board-listed stock was recently quoted at 28.23. It yields 1.8%.   ---   For Barron's subscription information call 1-888-BARRONS ext. 685 or inquire online at http://www.barronsmag.com/subscription/subscription.html.     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  January 13, 2007 00:07 ET (05:07 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Headline: UPDATE: 2 Miners Killed In W Virginia Coal Mine-Officials
Story: (Updates with mine owned by Alpha Natural Resources LLC; investigators going to scene)     CUCUMBER, W.Va. (AP)--A roof collapsed in a mine in West Virginia Saturday morning, killing two miners, authorities said.   The miners apparently were caught when a pillar fell, said Ron Wooten, director of the state Office of Miners' Health, Safety and Training. Wooten said rescuers were bringing their bodies to the surface.   "There's no need for rescue teams, the individuals have been recovered," he said.   Dispatchers said the accident happened up to 1 1/2 miles inside the Brooks Run mine in McDowell County.   Additional details weren't immediately available. Wooten said he expected to learn more when a team of investigators returns from underground.   The mine is owned by Alpha Natural Resources LLC. In October, a miner was killed in a wall collapse at Alpha's Whitetail Kittanning Mine in Newburg.   A year ago, an explosion killed 12 men at the Sago Mine in West Virginia's Upshur County. Also last January, two miners died in a fire at the Aracoma Alma No. 1 Mine in Logan County.   Cucumber is about 90 miles west of Roanoke, Va.     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  January 13, 2007 16:11 ET (21:11 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Headline: Barron's(1/15) Another Shoe Drops At Escala
Story: (From BARRON'S)     By Neil A. Martin   Troubled collectibles firm Escala Group was delisted by the Nasdaq Stock Market last week after it failed to meet deadlines for filing earnings for its fiscal year ended June 30 and its quarter ended Sept. 30.   The New York-based dealer in stamps, coins and other collectibles is under investigation by the Securities and Exchange Commission for alleged fraud in its dealings with its 67% owner, Spain's Afinsa Bienes Tangibles, the world's biggest stamp dealer, which itself is under investigation in Spain for criminal fraud and money laundering. Spanish authorities say the Madrid firm, who questionable practices Barron's highlighted two years ago ("Sticky Situation," May 23, 2005),  is insolvent and eventually will be liquidated.   Escala shares plummeted 42%, to $4.54, when the delisting notice was announced Tuesday, and finished the week near $4. The stock is off by nearly 90% from it all-time high of 35, reached last Feb. 8.   Traders say the stock will continue to decline as institutional holders are forced to liquidate their positions because of internal mandates that prohibit them from holding unlisted "pink sheet" stocks.   "It could fall below book value," says one of the few analysts who follows the company. The analyst estimates that after write-downs of inventory related to its Afinsa business and other business losses, Escala's 29.2 million shares have a per-share book value of around $2.30 to $2.60. "And if you take into account other yet-to-be calculated charges related to fighting shareholder lawsuits, the cost of the recent internal audit, the ongoing SEC investigation, what Spain might do with its shares of Escala, you can very easily get to a number around $1 a share in net asset value," he adds.   Also hanging over the stock are a number of issues unanswered by the company's recent internal audit, such as the details of a $21 million art donation in the June 2005 quarter that boosted Escala's earnings by 15 cents. Escala had never revealed who received this gift or who appraised the art.   Curiously, in government filings, it has characterized the value of the art as "de minimis" -- next to nothing.   ---   For Barron's subscription information call 1-888-BARRONS ext. 685 or inquire online at http://www.barronsmag.com/subscription/subscription.html.     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  January 13, 2007 00:06 ET (05:06 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Headline: Barron's(1/15) Research Reports: How Analysts Size Up Companies
Story: (From BARRON'S)     Edited By Anita Peltonen   The research reports excerpted here were issued recently by investment firms. Many may be obtained through Thomson Financial at www.thomson.com/financial or 800-638-8241. Some are available in the company-research area of WSJ.com, or through Factiva.com. Some of the reports' issuers have provided, or hope to provide, investment-banking or other services to the companies being analyzed.     Apple   -- AAPL-NNM     Outperform   -- Price 92.57 on Jan. 10   by Pacific Crest     The new iPhone appears to be a quantum leap forward in mobile devices, with Apple OS enabling a robust experience beyond that offered by competing devices. The high price and potential lack of complete corporate e-mail support are the only headwinds, in our view. Our 12-month price target of 100 is based on 35 times our calendar 2007 earnings-per-share estimate of $2.80. Market and macroeconomic conditions could interfere with realization of price target, as could . . . supply constraints on components for iPod, pricing pressures in Mac-systems business and potential channel disruption from opening of direct-to-consumer retail stores.     BankAtlantic Bancorp   -- BBX-NYSE     Hold   -- Price 13.55 on Jan. 9   by Sandler O'Neill     Target: 14. BBX announced . . . agreement to sell Ryan Beck Holdings, its wholly owned investment-banking subsidiary . . . to Stifel Financial (SF); close expected mid-February. Initial consideration will consist of about 2.531 million shares of SF common (valued at $96.4 million [as per Jan. 8] close). SF will also issue five-year warrants for purchase of up to 500,000 shares at exercise price of 36. . . . At 1.1 to 1.4 times book . . . we view the [deal] as fair.  . . . We've long viewed RB as among the weaker publicly traded regional brokerage franchises.     Bronco Drilling   -- BRNC-NNM     Outperform   -- Price 14.13 on Jan. 10   by Raymond James     Bronco announced it has acquired Eagle Well Service for $20.6 million. The acquisition includes 31 workover rigs. . . . Eagle operates in Oklahoma, Texas, Kansas and New Mexico.
