Headline: GE Shuts X-Ray Gear Plant Under Deal With US Regulators
Story: SALT LAKE CITY (AP)--A Salt Lake City medical manufacturer has been shut down after the U.S. Food and Drug Administration said its surgical imaging devices could put patients at risk.   The FDA announced a consent decree Friday with GE OEC Medical Systems, four months after an audit showed violations of federal quality assurance regulations. The company, a subsidiary of General Electric Co. (GE) since 1999, stopped shipping its fluoroscopic X-ray and navigation systems following the audit.   "These devices are used on thousands of patients, and their dependability and accuracy are critical for the successful outcomes of important medical procedures," according to Daniel Schulz, director of the FDA's Center for Devices and Radiological Health.   Under the FDA agreement, GE OEC can't manufacture or sell equipment until it complies with federal law. The agreement affects a Utah plant and a GE Healthcare plant in Lawrence, Mass. About 30 Utah employees have been placed on furlough.   Doctors commonly use the C-arm X-ray machines to see inside the body during minimally invasive orthopedic, cardiac and vascular surgeries.   GE Healthcare previously recalled the devices after learning that in some circumstances patients could be exposed to excessive radiation. The machines could also lose or mix up patient images after a procedure.   "The company takes FDA observations very seriously and is working aggressively to address and resolve the issues identified as quickly as possible," GE Healthcare spokesman Brian McKaig said.   As one condition of the decree, GE Healthcare must hire an independent expert to inspect the Utah and Massachusetts plants to make sure corrective measures are implemented.   FDA officials sent warning letters to the Utah plant in March 2005, noting quality control problems in manufacturing, packaging and equipment installation.     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  January 13, 2007 13:00 ET (18:00 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Headline: Barron's(1/15) he Striking Price: Predicting Profits Via Options
Story: (From BARRON'S)     By Steven M. Sears   During corporate earnings season, options trading will be to the financial market what canaries in birdcages once were to the mining industry. Everyone will look at put and call patterns, and especially volatility levels, to see if options are singing or silent ahead of reports.   High-volatility options will indicate stocks that traders think are primed to make a sharp move. Low-volatility options will spotlight stocks expected to barely budge on earnings. Earnings season, which began late Tuesday when Alcoa (AA) reported a 60% increase in fourth-quarter profits, will pace trading for the next few weeks.   Already, earnings-trading lists are circulating to help traders and portfolio managers decide how to position for earnings. The companies on the lists have been dissected into so many data points and then reassembled to try to quantify how their stocks behaved in past earnings cycles, and to predict how they might respond this time.   Goldman Sachs' initial earnings trading menu has Netflix (NFLX) leading the list of high-volatility issues expected to move on earnings. Netflix's options imply a 20% one-day earnings move, up or down. Other stocks Goldman identified as having unusually high implied moves are Silicon Laboratories (SLAB) and Steel Dynamics (STLD) at 16%, Corning (GLW) and Sandisk (SNDK) at 15%, Coach (COH) at 13%, and St. Jude Medical (STJ) and WR Grace at 12%.   Traders fundamentally have two primary opportunities with high-volatility options. They can sell because they think volatility will decline when the earnings are released, or they can buy to participate in the big stock move anticipated by the options.   Low-volatility options, which usually include mega-cap stocks, are often attractive to bullish traders who buy inexpensive options as stock surrogates. Options prices for Intel (INTC), Eli Lilly (LLY), General Electric (GE) and Pfizer (PFE) imply the stocks may move about 2% on earnings.   If past quarters are any indication, conclusions about these and other stocks will emerge in the options market the day before these companies are scheduled to release their profit reports.   Earnings-related trading will likely focus on options with strike prices close to the underlying stock's current price, extending an ongoing trend in the options market in which traders primarily remain unwilling to expose themselves to big losses or gains.   This essentially defensive stance is starting to manifest itself in index options, as traders seek to protect portfolios from whatever turbulence earnings might unleash in a broad market that many believe is poised to decline from its record-high level.   Sales traders are starting to recommend that clients buy what they call "1x2" downside protection. This entails acquiring one at-the-money put on a major index and paying for it by selling two slightly out-of-the money puts. These positions will rise in value if stock prices slip modestly, but will prove treacherous if the market falls sharply below the short puts' strike prices.   So far, these trades are appearing in the iShares Russell 2000 Index (IWM), as well as exchange-traded funds that track the S&P 500 (SPY) and Nasdaq-100 (QQQQ).   ---   For Barron's subscription information call 1-888-BARRONS ext. 685 or inquire online at http://www.barronsmag.com/subscription/subscription.html.     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  January 13, 2007 00:05 ET (05:05 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Headline: Barron's(1/15) European Trader: Caution: Don t Exaggerate SAP s Woes
Story: (From BARRON'S)     By Arindam Nag and Steve McGrath   The valuation premium that SAP enjoys over rivals like Oracle and Microsoft is in danger.   Shares of SAP, the world's largest seller of business software, fell more than 10% Thursday in trading in New York, closing at $48.50. Triggering the drop was the company's preliminary disclosure that its software-license sales had risen a disappointing 7% in the fourth quarter.   With two revenue warnings in a year from the German software company, its ability to deliver incremental growth ahead of its rivals in 2007 is in doubt. Management will have to change tack by erring on the side of caution when providing sales and earnings guidance. SAP (ticker: SAP) is slated to do that next at its 2006 earnings report Jan. 24.   But pressure also is on management to give a firmer commitment for the early launch of its mid-market product range, expected in the second half, on which much of SAP's future growth depends.   That said, it would be wrong to exaggerate SAP's difficulties or say that it's giving up incremental market share to arch rival Oracle (ORCL), especially after the U.S. company's own latest quarterly numbers were disappointing. Oracle's organic growth declined, while that of SAP's license revenues, on a constant-currency basis, gained 12%.   Drilling through the numbers, discounting currency changes, the shortfall in software sales is just 40 million euros from the lower end of range -- not huge for a company that generates over 9 billion euros in annual sales. That may be why SAP stock mounted somewhat of a comeback Friday, rising 3.3%, to 50.10.   Two factors have gone against SAP: the weak dollar and sluggish advances in newer markets -- such as the public sector and financial services -- in the U.S. The weak greenback means dollar income translates into lower euro earnings, while SAP products become less competitive in dollar zones.   So 15% constant-currency U.S. growth translated into just a 4% gain in the fourth quarter. Revenue growth also fell in Latin America, leading to no growth over all in the Americas. Revenue in the Asia Pacific region, where many currencies are pegged to the dollar, shrank. Europe was the sole bright spot.   The main question for investors is how much of SAP's current premium is at risk. Before Friday's warning, the stock traded at 28 times average 2006 earnings forecasts, versus 18 times for Oracle and 21 for Microsoft (MSFT).   Much depends on SAP's ability to hold down discretionary spending, plus the timing of the launch of the new mid-market products.     It didn't take long for Volkswagen's new chief executive, Martin Winterkorn, to undo his predecessor's management structure and strategy. That leaves investors bracing for a possible slowdown in the restructuring at Europe's biggest car maker.   The architects of VW's revamping over the past few years -- former CEO Bernd Pischetsrieder and head of the VW brand group Wolfgang Bernhard -- have been replaced.   One part of their plan -- grouping brands in two separate units to extract synergies like component sharing -- is being shelved. The brands -- VW, Skoda, Seat, Lamborghini, Audi, Bentley and Bugatti -- are now free to operate as they wish, though there are new management positions to make sure they're not pulling in different directions and ignoring opportunities for cost savings.   Winterkorn's shakeup casts doubt over the determination of Volkswagen (ticker: VOW.Frankfurt) to sort out its key problem: the high cost of its German operations. It had taken Pischetsrieder and Bernhard two years of tough negotiations to drive through 20,000 job cuts and a new labor deal in Germany. There are signs that it has worked for now, as the VW brand's profitability has started to rise.   But Winterkorn doesn't have the same record on restructuring. As head of the Audi group under Pischetsrieder, he had ultimate responsibility for turning around Spanish unit Seat, where he achieved mixed results. The cars are undoubtedly better, but the unit remains unprofitable. What's more, new measures to address VW's German costs were noticeably absent from his strategy statement Thursday.   There's also the Ferdinand Piech factor. Winterkorn is a close ally of VW's supervisory board chairman. In fact, the new management structure at VW looks very similar to the structure that was in place when Piech was CEO.   VW is enjoying some momentum. VW, Skoda and Audi are selling well, and the company is profitable. But with the auto maker yet to find a solution to making money in the U.S. market -- and in no need of more pet projects like Piech's luxury flop, the Phaeton -- the Piech-Winterkorn axis hasn't proved it can keep restructuring going in Germany so that earnings keep improving.   ---   Arindam Nag and Steve McGrath, who are based in London, contribute to The Skeptic, a Dow Jones Newswires column on which this European Trader is based.   ---                           DOW JONES GLOBAL INDEXES    Region/  Country     DJ Global          DJ Global          DJ Global     Point      Indexes,           Indexes,           Indexes,      Chg.    % Chg. Headline: Barron's(1/15) 2007 Barron's Roundtable: Speaking -4-
Story: Gross: One macro point: We make a mistake -- and I've made the same mis- take -- focusing exclusively on real GDP. We assume a 2% real GDP number is a Goldilocks number. It's not too hot or too cold, and it's certainly not a recession. In so doing, we fail to focus on nominal GDP, which is buried in the Commerce Department's press release. In a debt-laden economy that requires appreciation of the nominal economy to service its debt, nominal GDP is critical. In 2007, it is nominal GDP that stands a chance of encountering a recession. I don't mean it goes below zero, because that rarely if ever has happened. But a nominal-GDP recession is somewhere in the 3% to 4% vicinity. It is at that point that asset appreciation begins to go in reverse, which is what we're really talking about in terms of a market outlook.   Oil is about 8% of the total CPI package. When oil prices decline by 20% or so, you see a 11/2% to 2% subtraction from core CPI. The consumer-price index will be in the 1% zone, plus or minus, by midyear, which means nominal GDP will be approaching 3%. Be careful about forecasting nominal earnings growth of 6% or 8% or 10% in a world in which the nominal U.S. economy is only going to grow by 3%-4%.     Q: Let's go on to the stock market. Felix?   Zulauf: This will be a transition year to a better '08-'09. There will be a shakeout at some point, and some difficulties in corporate earnings. What I'm not sure about is the timing of the shakeout. The market is overheated and trends are aging or losing power. Particularly if the carry trade [borrowing at low rates to purchase higher-yielding assets] goes into reverse -- if the yen suddenly starts to strengthen -- some players will have to reduce their leverage and sell.     Q: What does that imply for rates?   Zulauf: You could have a brutal correction in all asset markets. One is on the way in commodities, which began topping last May. If commodities peaked last spring, they could make a low around the middle of '07. A lot of aggressive money is positioned on the long side in commodities. That's a problem, together with those who have financed carry-trade positions in yen. If the yen goes against them, they will either have to hedge the yen -- meaning they will buy it and push it up more -- or reduce their asset side. All these things together could lead to a brutal shakeout in the next few months. There could be a 15% to 20% drop in the general markets. That would be the better outcome because it would clear the markets of excess and bring the central banks in to loosen credit. A good shakeout first would be a wonderful scenario. Then the market could go up, slowly at first, accelerating over the next two to three years. If the corrective process in the first few months of '07 is shallow and mild, we'll have one later, from a higher level. But the odds are it will happen sooner.     Q: Art, what do you think about the market and interest rates?   Samberg: Rates will probably go up and then go down. The economy is having a little bounce. Later this year there will be a slowdown, and rates will come down by maybe half a percentage point, not much.   Zuluaf: Are you talking short or long rates?   Samberg: I am talking short. As for the market, I hope we get a correction early on. You know there will be a correction sometime, with the VIX [volatility index] so low. I don't see why there should be a huge one. But there are those asset shufflers. Others, like me, call them asset allocators.   Gabelli: Asset enhancers, hopefully.   Samberg: John is involved with some investment committees and so am I. The world is a helluva lot different than it used to be. One committee I'm on had a ton of money with one U.S. long-only manager, and it no longer does. The committee's portfolio was up 23% last year for the fiscal year ended June 2006. There has been a much greater allocation of institutional money into hard assets and other things. When then happens, you have to look not only at economic growth, but all the financial strategies that go on around it. You could have a melt-up in commodities that is futures driven, not physically driven. It complicates relationships. You've got to look below the surface and find out what's really going on.     Q: Abby, what do you think?   Cohen: I'm bullish this year, but not as much as last year. At this time last year, the S&P was around 1250. Using fundamentally driven models, we predicted it would close at 1400, which is roughly where it is now. Using the same models, we are estimating a fair value of 1550 at the end of this year. We always like to give ourselves some headwinds, however, so I'm assuming 6% or 6.5% nominal earnings growth. The surprise there could be to the upside. Our earnings-growth estimate would be more robust, except we are assuming a sharp deceleration in the growth of energy-company profits.   More important from a mathematical standpoint, we are making some unpleasant assumptions about interest rates. The Fed will look at a weak-ish economy in the next several months, and may lower interest rates. Not much is going to happen to intermediate- and long-bond yields, but I like to be conservative in my model so I assume intermediates will rise by 75 basis points [a basis point is one one-hundredth of a percentage point] from current levels. Those are the numbers I'm using to come up with 1550. I disagree with the people around this table who said the U.S. equity market is overpriced. I just don't see it. On a P/E-ratio basis, which is not our preferred approach, the market is trading at about 16 times earnings. At previous periods when core inflation was at roughly these levels, the median P/E was about 181/2 times earnings.     Q: Is there anything that worries you?   Cohen: We've gotten accustomed to extraordinarily low volatility. The standard deviation of daily price changes has been running at about 8%. The historical average in the U.S. is 16% to 18%. The combination of high liquidity and low volatility around the world helps to explain the significant risk appetite demonstrated by many investors. If volatility moves toward more normal levels, we might start to see some disruptive patterns. One problem might lie in the narrow yield spreads among lower-rated corporate bonds. Also, in the U.S., the relative valuation is roughly the same for large-cap and small-cap, high-quality and low-quality stocks. If volatility begins rising and liquidity diminishes, portfolio managers will move to higher-quality issues.   Black: Abby's right on P/Es. The S&P and the Russell 2000 Value index are pretty much homogeneously priced. But on a price-to-book-value basis there are significant differences. The S&P 500 is one full multiple point higher, at about 2.8 times book. The others trade at about 1.8 and 1.85 times book. If you go back to the theories of Fama and French [Professors Eugene Fama and Kenneth French], companies with smaller capitalizations and lower price-to-book values do better over time.   Cohen: They do particularly well if they survive.   Black: I said I'm modestly bullish. Many of the tech stocks Fred covers are not cheap. They trade at 17, 18, 20 multiples of earnings. A lot of the bigger consumer-staples names are single-digit top-line growers with 18 and 19 P/Es. It's the same with pharmaceuticals. It's a fallacy to think large-cap growth is the place to be. You are paying excessive P/E-to-growth ratios for them. You can do much better on a case-by-case basis in small and mid-cap values.   Cohen: I didn't say growth stocks. I said high-quality. When I talk about the relative value of different groups, this is risk-adjusted.     Q: Scott, where are interest rates headed?   Black: Long-bond yields are headed down -- to 4.25%-4.50%.   Gross: Volatility isn't the only element of pricing, but it is a critical one. That's true whether you're talking about the volatility of oil prices or interest rates or the stock market. To the extent that it is low, we see it as a synonym for complacency. If it is at an abnormally low level, an increase would have an effect on financial markets.   Meryl, what are you looking for in interest rates, even though you don't look at interest rates?   Meryl: I use a discounted-free-cash-flow model, employing discount rates of 10% to 12%. If the yield on the 10-year is at 4.24%-4.75%, it doesn't matter.   MacAllaster: Interest rates aren't coming down. The Fed will stay right where it is, at 5.25%, or go higher. At some point, you're going to have to protect the dollar. In order to keep the dollar stable against the euro and the rest, you may have to raise rates.     Q: Fred, what do you think?   Hickey: With my outlook on the economy, I don't think interest rates are going higher. They are going lower. We will have at least a 10% correction in stocks. The trucking index already is at recession levels. Everyone seems complacent out there.     Q: In here, too. Do you think tech stocks will be a buy 10% lower?   Hickey: They will. If we get a bear market, we'll finally get the capitulation stage in tech. Technology stocks have underperformed the market for six or seven years. For the past three years, the Philadelphia Semiconductor Index was down 14%. In the U.S. market, which was one of the worst-performing stock markets last year, you couldn't find a worse group than semiconductors. Yet among managers surveyed by Frank Russell, tech still was the most popular sector. Two-thirds were bullish on tech at the end of 2006. When we get a bear market and the stocks capitulate, I'll come here and give you 55 tech names to buy.     Q: How many years will that be?   Hickey: The capitulation hasn't occurred, yet the fundamentals keep deteriorating. There's tremendous price pressure in tech. In my world, contract manufacturers are talking about major downturns, big declines in order rates. A Sanford Bernstein report said there were inventory increases at every level of the food chain in tech. If the economy sinks as a result of the housing downturn, tech will be a disaster.     Q: Is there any point to bonds at all?   (MORE TO FOLLOW) Dow Jones Newswires  January 13, 2007 00:04 ET (05:04 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Headline: Barron's(1/15) Barron's Mailbag: Ma Bell's An Optimist
Story: (From BARRON'S)   To the Editor:     The premise of "AT&T Unplugged" (Cover Story, Jan. 1) is that AT&T must execute its business strategy to continue its strong market success. Isn't that true of any company? At the end of the day, execution is the key, no matter your industry or circumstances. AT&T excels at execution, and investors have recognized that fact, bidding up the company's stock 46% in 2006 and prompting 19 analysts who follow the company for a living to give it a Buy rating.   Inexplicably absent from your story is the reason for all the optimism around AT&T: strong execution that has led to growth in earnings per share, growth in cash flow, growth in adjusted operating-income margins, growth in data revenues, growth in wireless revenues and growth in consumer and small business in-region revenues. In fact, AT&T has experienced six straight quarters of adjusted double-digit, year-over-year earnings-per-share growth, and we expect the same in 2007 and 2008.   While cable has made some inroads in the consumer wireline market, we've grown our revenue per household in each quarter of 2006, and we're just now entering the video market, which is nothing but upside for us. Our two video services -- one fiber-based and the other satellite based -- provide exciting entertainment options.   With the BellSouth merger complete, AT&T has the industry's best set of wireless and wireline assets.   As your article states, AT&T "made her fans both happy and rich in 2006." Headline: Barron's(1/15) Asian Trader: Aussie Grocer's Gamble After Spurning Offer
Story: (From BARRON'S)     By Susan Murdoch   A consortium led by U.S. private-equity giant Kohlberg Kravis Roberts was hastily shown the door in October by Australia's second-largest retailer, Coles Group. But since then, a string of bad news for the supermarket operator has some betting that buyout groups may pounce again.   Private-equity firms have a natural attraction to retailers like Coles (ticker: CGJ.Australia). Solid and reliable cash flows enable the rapid paydown of debt, and a well-known brand ensuresmaximum recognition when the business is returned to the stock exchange.   Australia's supermarket sector is a near-duopoly, with Coles holding around 35% of the market and rival Woolworths, 40%. Says analyst Grant Saligari of Commonwealth Securities in Sydney: "Even though Coles has lagged Woolworths in terms of operating performance, you've got a business with virtually the same retail footprint across the country."   Yet a sizable gap has opened between the two in the food and liquor business, which accounts for about two-thirds of Coles' earnings before interest and taxes. In the past five years, Goldman Sachs JBWere calculates, Woolworths' average annual EBIT growth has been 16%, versus Coles' 9%. Coles is trailing Woolworths in overhauling its supply chain, giving its rival a jump on converting cost savings to lower prices.   The potential to easily carve up the company also makes it an appealing target: Coles owns profitable discount department-store chain Target -- unrelated to the U.S. retailer of the same name -- and office supplier Officeworks, which could both be offloaded to unlock value.   Coles Chairman Rick Allert took less than 24 hours to reject the KKR-led consortium's proposal of 15.25 Australian dollars a share on Oct. 19, up from an earlier A$14.50 offer, saying the revised figure "still substantially undervalued the company and its prospects."   The board has instead put its faith in the turnaround strategy of CEO John Fletcher, who has pledged an ambitious 35% increase in net profit, to A$1.07 billion, in fiscal 2008. Part of the plan involves slashing 2,500 administrative jobs in 18 months. It also will streamline its supermarket and liquor operations under a single Coles brand.   There is no shortage of skeptics, however, with some analysts concerned that the job cuts will devastate morale and jeopardize the group's transformation: Coles' first sales results since spurning the A$18.2 billion offer disappointed the market. The food-and-liquor division booked a 3.3% rise in same-store sales for the three months to Oct. 29, compared with Woolworths' fiscal first-quarter gain of 4.9%.   Confidence was further dented by the surprise sacking in November of a senior supermarket executive amid allegations of related-party dealings. And Coles' largest shareholder, Premier Investments, has launched a landmark legal action seeking access to confidential documents the board used to justify its rejection of the buyout. Premier Investments, with a 5.8% stake, is controlled by former Coles Chairman Solomon Lew. He was dumped as a director in 2002, and the billionaire retail magnate has since been a relentless critic of the board and its management.   Somewhat perversely, the run of bad news has seen Coles' share price rise -- likely on expectations that the woes will put pressure on the board to engage in talks with any future buyer.Since rejection of the Oct. 19 offer, the stock has risen more than 6%, closing Friday at A$14.07.   Australia is seeing what Carlyle Group founder David Rubenstein terms a "land rush" by cash-rich buyout groups. KKR made its first investment in Australia last June, buying the waste-management business Cleanaway for A$1.83 billion. A month after walking away from Coles, it struck a A$4 billion deal with media group Seven Network in November.   Several other large buyout funds have been involved in a number of deals with Australian companies, including CVC Asia Pacific and Texas Pacific Group (CVC formed a A$4.5 billion media joint venture with Publishing & Broadcasting and Texas Pacific is part of the consortium bidding A$11.1 billion for Qantas Airways) -- helping to keep Coles under the radar, at least until it reports first-half results in March. The company has forecast a flat annual profit of A$787 million for the fiscal year ending July 30 as restructuring costs peak.   Analysts are skeptical of Coles' ability to hit its targets next year, with the consensus of a A$933 million net profit more than 14% below the company's forecast, according to a Thomson Financial survey of nine analysts.   Atul Lele, a fund manager at Sydney-based White Funds Management, says if first-half results disappoint, a price close to KKR's offer of A$15.25 could be enough to win over some shareholders. But given the market's skepticism, there's definite upside if Coles delivers better-than-expected results.   "But to be on track, they will need to demonstrate solid sales momentum, not just costs reduction," says analyst Saligari. If it fails, whether the buyout funds return is anyone's guess. If they do, and there's a successful bid, it would mark the biggest corporate takeover in Australia's history.   ---   Susan Murdoch reports for Dow Jones Newswires from Melbourne.   ---   For Barron's subscription information call 1-888-BARRONS ext. 685 or inquire online at http://www.barronsmag.com/subscription/subscription.html.     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  January 13, 2007 00:06 ET (05:06 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Headline: US Democrats: Will Extend Minimum Wage To American Samoa
Story: WASHINGTON (AP)--Fending off charges of favoritism, House Democrats say a just-passed minimum wage bill will be changed to cover all U.S. territories - including American Samoa - before it reaches President George W. Bush's desk.   House Speaker Nancy Pelosi, a California Democrat, told reporters she instructed the House Education and Labor Committee to help get the bill changed to "make sure that all of the territories have to comply with the U.S. law on minimum wage."   Her remark Friday followed accusations from Republicans that American Samoa, which is not now covered by the $5.15 an hour federal minimum wage, was not included in the law raising the wage to $7.25 an hour because StarKist has a large cannery in the island chain. StarKist is owned by Del Monte Foods Co. (DLM), which has its headquarters in San Francisco, Pelosi's district.   "Something is indeed fishy when the federal minimum wage is good for all Americans as espoused by the Democrat majority, yet we exempt a small, in many terms economically struggling island," Rep. Patrick McHenry, a North Carolina Republican, told colleagues on the House floor last week.   The bill was passed Wednesday by the House as part of the Democrats' 100-hour agenda. The measure covers another U.S. territory, the Northern Mariana Islands, which had been shielded in the past from the wage law with the help of former House Majority Leader Tom DeLay, a Texas Republican, and Republican lobbyist Jack Abramoff, now in prison.   Spokesmen for both Pelosi and Rep. George Miller, a California Democrat and the author of the minimum wage bill, said it excluded American Samoa at the request of nonvoting Delegate Eni Faleomavaega, a Democrat who represents the Pacific island territories in the House.   Raising the federal minimum wage would devastate the local tuna industry, Faleomavaega said in a statement last week, noting that American Samoa's economy is "more than 80 percent" dependent on two U.S. tuna processors, Chicken of the Sea and StarKist. Faleomavaega said the Labor Department reviews Samoa's minimum wages every two years.     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  January 13, 2007 15:33 ET (20:33 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Headline: Barron's(1/15) 2007 Barron's Roundtable: Speaking -5-
Story: Gross: They provide current income. There's a point. [Laughter around the room.] There are two significant players -- bookends -- in the bond market: central banks, and the recyclers of reserve monies we've been speaking of here. These include the OPEC nations and Asian nations that tend to be rather price insensitive. These entities recycle money for reasons other than the yield on a bond. They recycle it to support the dollar and de-floor their own currencies, and for a number of geopolitical reasons. Everybody else is sort of in the middle.   Pimco manages $650 billion, which is about 1% of all of the bond monies in the world. You would think we are a big factor in determining where rates go. But we don't go all long or all short, so the changes we make don't tend to make much of a difference. The bookends are the major determiners of value in the bond market.     Q: What are they planning to do?   Gross: If, as I predict, nominal GDP grows by 3% to 4% in the next three to six months, the Fed will have to react. That's too disinflationary, almost deflationary, for a 5.25% rate not to adjust downward. In the second half of the year, assuming some type of retracement by other asset markets, the Fed will cut the federal-funds rate to perhaps as little as 4.25% to restimulate the nominal economy.   That doesn't necessarily mean the bond market does well. The outlook for bonds is determined more by the reserve recyclers and the amount of money they have to invest. Those monies will be declining. OPEC nations will have $200 billion to $300 billion less to invest. They don't invest in the Treasury market, but a lot of their money winds up there. That is one of the reasons why, if oil stays where it is, longer-dated Treasury yields stand a chance of going up.     Q: Does anyone think oil prices will rise?   Black: I do, but modestly. There are about 2.9 million barrels of surplus supply per day. Demand is around 84.5 million barrels a day, and supplies are at about 87 million. China uses seven million barrels a day on its way to 10 million. India is growing, too.   Most of the major fields have peaked, with the possible exceptions of Angola, Gabon, Nigeria and Brazil.Norway just peaked. There is not a lot of swing capacity. On a secular basis, the price will go back to the mid-$60s. A price of $57 a barrel [crude fell below $54 last week] is a little too low. The irony is that oil companies make a ton of money at $57 a barrel anyway.   Zulauf: Surprisingly, high prices haven't killed demand. Oil will continue to trade in a $50 to $70 range, plus or minus $5. If global economies do better, oil will break to the upside and we'll see new highs again.     Q: No one has mentioned Iraq. Will the war have any impact on the economy and financial markets?   MacAllaster: Unless they make progress, it will. If there is no progress in the next two years, there will be a Democratic president in the U.S.   Zulauf: Getting out of Iraq won't improve the demand-supply situation for oil. It will get worse before it gets better.   Faber: Oil, like other industrial-commodity prices, overshot on the upside. Now it can go down; the correction can be substantial, even in a bull market, It wouldn't surprise me to see oil at $45 before it goes to $200.   I don't understand why you measure the market's performance strictly in dollars. Since 2000, the euro has appreciated 60% against the U.S. dollar. The Dow Jones is at a new high, but it's down 38% in euros. I agree with Felix that the stock market has peaked temporarily. Once the Dow has dropped 10%, the Fed will print money like water. But that doesn't mean bonds will rally. The Fed could bring short-term rates down, but long rates will go up as a result of the currency.   Gabelli: Asian central banks want to keep buying U.S. bonds.   Faber: Even Asian central bankers will one day realize it is not in their best interest to be long U.S. bonds.   Black: There is a symbiotic relationship between these countries and the U.S. It may be sloppy economics on the part of the U.S., but China won't continue to grow by 8 1/2%-9% a year if it doesn't export to us.     Q: Will the euro and pound keep rising?   Faber: The British pound is overvalued vis-a-vis the U.S. dollar. The euro is fully valued against the dollar. Asian currencies have appreciation potential, but all paper money will continue to depreciate against precious metals. Gold went from $255 an ounce in 2001 to $730. It's around $606 today. It may go down to $480-$550, but in the long run it will go up more than the Dow. This year I want it on my buy list.   Samberg: This whole bull market got started when the Berlin Wall fell and communism died.   Faber: No, it started in 1982.   Samberg: That's the way you measure it. I have mine. Now that Russia owns Europe, tell me, what has changed?   Zulauf: About 70% of Western Europe's energy comes from outside the region. About a quarter of that comes from Russia. Although Europe has virtually no foreign policy, it is slowly developing one relative to Russia. It needs Russia.   Samberg: We're in trouble. Europe's a wholly owned subsidiary of Russia.   Faber: That is not the case. The U.S. has managed, through its inept foreign policy, to drive Russia and China together. They will never vote with the U.S. in the U.N. Security Council. They have a common interest in Central Asia. Russia and China have no interest whatsoever in the U.S. succeeding in the Middle East. They will try to undermine the authority of the U.S. in the Middle East and Africa and Latin America.   Zulauf: And keep the U.S. busy in the Middle East while they get Africa's resources.   Faber: Mr. Bush is the greatest president to the Russians and Chinese. But I don't want to sound anti-American . . .     Q: Let's switch to stocks. Scott? Remember, we're not talking about paintings.   Black: I can't find low-P/E paintings anymore. They don't exist. To reiterate Meryl's comments, this is one of the more difficult periods, if you're a deep-value player, to find outstanding values. We have two out-of-favor larger names, and four microcaps I doubt you've heard of. They all have a common theme: high return on equity, low P/E, low price-to-break-up value, with free-cash-flow generation. My first stock, Apache [ticker: APA], based in Houston, is a large oil exploration and production company. Reserves have grown for 21 consecutive years. It has exploration properties worldwide. The stock closed Jan. 5 at 65.25. There are 329 million shares, and a $21.5 billion market cap. We buy companies as ongoing concerns, but we're not oblivious to private-equity values. This one is selling for 4.1 times enterprise value to Ebitda. It has a 25% return on equity.     Q: Have you tried to sell it to somebody?   Black: No. Net debt to equity is about 0.27. Return on total capital is more than 20%. The company is a powerhouse. This year it's going to grow 8% to 10% from the drillbit, excluding acquisitions. Forty-two percent of its reserve value is in the U.S.; 27% is in Canada, with 9% in Australia and the North Sea, and 13% in Egypt. Apache is now the third-largest producer of energy in Egypt.   Crude is selling for $57 a barrel and natural gas for $6 per thousand cubic feet [mcf]. When the company does its capital budgets and ROE calculations, it assumes $40 oil and $4.50 per mcf for gas. We have them earning about $7.90 a share this year, up from an estimated $7.55. They'll generate about $2.6 billion in net income. Depreciation and amortization are $2.1 billion. Deferred taxes are about $614 million, which gives them $5.3 billion in sources of income. They should generate $1.6 billion of free cash.     Q: What is the break-up value?   Black: Last year they had 976 million barrels of oil. I gave them $12 of net present value. They had 6.85 trillion cubic feet [tcf] of gas. I used $3 per mcf, but did a sensitivity analysis at $2.50 per mcf. They have acquired properties in the Gulf of Mexico with a net present value of $678 million. They acquired 22 million barrels in the U.S. and added 297 billion cubic feet [bcf] of gas in Argentina. That's $1.15 billion. They have some new pipelines which we accounted for at book value, $203 million. They bought 27 million barrels of oil and 27 bcf of gas in the Permian Basin, which is worth $404 million. Add this together, subtract net debt and you get a break-up value of $29.5 billion, or $89.50 a share.     Q: What do you get with $2.50 gas?   Black: De-escalating to $2.50 per mcf on a net-present-value basis knocks out about $11 a share. You still have $79. At 65.25 the stock sells for 8.2 times this year's estimated earnings. At a break-up value of $78.50 it would sell for 0.83 times its conservative liquidating value. It's cheap.   Apache has two potential home runs in the 2008 area. In Egypt, gas production should increase by about 50%. Apache also is exploring in the Bass Strait in Australia. ExxonMobil [XOM] and BHP [BHP] already have found four billion barrels of oil and 5.5 tcf of natural gas there. This is a contrarian play because the oil and gas sector is out of favor. Unfortunately, people don't look at the absolute value of oil; they look at daily price fluctuations. The hedge-fund money goes in and out. Even with gas at $6 per mcf and oil at roughly $58-$60 a barrel, these companies are making a fortune. The stock could go to $85-$90 a share. At some point, somebody in the private-equity space will discover Apache, because it is an excellent company. There aren't many companies of this size that earn 20% on book and generate $1.6 billion in free cash.     Q: How about another name?   (MORE TO FOLLOW) Dow Jones Newswires  January 13, 2007 00:04 ET (05:04 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Headline: Barron's(1/15) The Trader: As Oil Falls, The Dow Becomes A Gusher
Story: (From BARRON'S)     By Vito J. Racanelli   There's something to be said for serendipity. Take plunging energy and commodity prices, for example. Not long ago, few would have expected to see oil drop like a stone, but it has. And that continued last week.   Throw in continued robust economic news, and it's no surprise that share prices rose solidly last week. Tech stocks led the way, despite a couple of profit warnings Friday from big names in the group.   "It was like looking at a slot machine spin and seeing three cherries show up," says Fritz Meyer, senior investment officer for AIM Advisors, of the string of favorable factors last week.   Though crude recovered some Friday, it fell another 6% for the week, to about $53 a barrel, and is already down 13% in the first few days of the new year, while copper and other industrial metals are also falling. Oil is now down about a third from highs of $77 per barrel last summer.   Meanwhile, for all the angst about the recent holiday selling season, retail sales surprised on the upside. Friday, the Commerce Department said that December retail sales increased by a seasonally adjusted 0.9%, nicely above Street expectations of 0.7%.   Wall Street economists, who've generally been looking for a U.S. slowdown in 2007 "are breaking out in a sweat," Meyer says. There's been very little negative economic data over the past few weeks, so the market is getting a sense the U.S. economy is evolving more favorably than previously thought, Meyers adds. And worries that a Fed rate cut would come late or even not at all have been forgotten -- at least for now -- offset by those lower commodity prices, he adds.   The Dow Jones Industrial Average rose 1.3%, to 12,556, a record close. The Standard & Poor's 500 tacked on 1.5%, to 1,430.73, and the tech-heavy Nasdaq Composite Index jumped nearly 3%, to 2502.82. Tech giants like AMD (ticker: AMD) and SAP (SAP; see page M9) gave profit warnings Friday, but it wasn't enough to derail the upward move.   Investor confidence in the U.S. economy seemed to improve almost day by day last week, says James Weiss, chief investment officer of Weiss Capital Management. Just a few weeks ago, there was a worry that a Fed cut was needed as lubrication to keep the economy chugging along, "but now the thinking is the market can do it itself," adds Weiss. He's looking for "a very acceptable" 7%-8% growth in 2007 corporate earnings expansion. "Corporate profits will drive the market this year," he said. "Two to three percent growth would be problematic."   Investors will have plenty of new fodder on that score soon. The fourth-quarter earnings season should kick off in earnest this week, when trading resumes after the Martin Luther King holiday. Alcoa (AA) started things off on the right track: Tuesday, the giant aluminum maker produced fourth quarter profits that topped Wall Street forecasts, sending its shares up 7% on the week.     Delta Air Lines (DALQR), the bankrupt legacy carrier, received an improved, unsolicited tender offer from US Airways (LCC) last week. The latter bumped up its previous bid by about 20% to $10.4 billion, in the form of 89.5 million of its own shares plus $5 billion in cash. At the same time, there were also renewed press reports that Northwest Airlines, also in bankruptcy, was talking to Atlanta-based Delta about a merger.   Unsurprisingly, Delta's bonds rose. Should US Airways' offer be accepted -- or a better one from Northwest comes along -- that's more money for the creditors and bondholders when Delta exits bankruptcy, probably later this year.   But why has Delta's stock been rising? The shares of this belly-up carrier have been on a tear since the summer. Though the stock fell 12 cents Friday, to $1.34, it had been up 13%, to $1.48, by Thursday. It's stil up 34% in the last two months and has doubled since August. Delta's market capitalization is now $264 million.   In any bankruptcy, there might be some minor recovery value, but the rich history of airline insolvencies has shown there's typically no scraps left for common shareholders. They usually get wiped out. Even if a bid were to materialize from bankrupt Northwest, it's hard to imagine the bulk of it going anywhere but to Delta's creditors.   So what gives?   "It's naive money and people trading," says veteran airline analyst Ray Neidl of Calyon Securities. He believes the Delta stock is "highly likely to be worthless in any restructuring."   Consider that Delta's 8.3% notes due 2029 traded up on the news by more than five cents, to as high as 70 cents on the dollar at one point, he adds. Yet that's still far below par. Bondholders "don't think they are going to get full value...so they aren't going to let shareholders get anything if they aren't made whole first."   While it's impossible to rule out the chance that Delta's shareholders might get something, there's not a lot of airline bankruptcy precedent to support that possibility, he adds.   Trading in Delta stock is purely speculative and a bit like playing musical chairs right now. But as the company reaches the bankruptcy exit door, it might start to feel more like Russian roulette for Delta shareholders.     With a market value of nearly $32 billion, Kimberly-Clark (KMB) is obviously a large-cap stock, but it generally flies under the radar screen. You don't read much about it, even if 1.3 billion people -- as the maker of Kleenex tissues and Huggies diapers says -- use its health and hygiene products every day.   But a big upswell in Kimberly call options activity last month caught the attention of B. Craig Hutson, a credit analyst at Chicago's Gimme Credit, an independent bond research shop. Call options are the right to buy a stock at a stated price within a specified period; heavy buying of calls suggests that some investors expect a higher stock price ahead. At one point, the trading was almost 20 times the normal volume, Hutson notes.   And the company's bonds have performed poorly, Hutson adds, on unconfirmed whispers of a possible leveraged buyout (LBO). Since mid-September the spread between Kimberly's bond yield and the benchmark 10-year Treasury bond yield have widened sharply, by 30 basis points to some 90 basis points. That suggests bondholders are getting antsy about the LBO rumors.   Meanwhile, Kimberly's stock has caught fire, hitting a 52-week high of about 69.48 last week, up 17% in the last six months, and is also outperforming rival stocks like Procter & Gamble (PG) and Clorox (CLX), though the latter reported better operating performance last year.   Despite Kimberly's recent share gains, its enterprise value (EV) to earnings before interest, taxes and depreciation (Ebitda) multiple of about 10.5 times 2006 estimates is still significantly below its large, high quality consumer products peers. P&G currently trades at about 13.5 times, Clorox at 12 times.   The rumors haven't been substantiated, but could a company as large as Kimberly be a potential LBO candidate? Even after the big runup in the stock price, Hutson answers "Yes." The company declined to comment both on the rumors and the Gimme Credit report.   Hutson figures a 20% premium to the current price would value Kimberly at $41 billion, or about 12.5 times trailing Ebidta, and such an LBO would make it the biggest to date. Compared to the average deal, that would be a rich multiple, but P&G paid an 18.8 times multiple for Gillette in 2005.   But this wouldn't be an average deal, as Kimberly has many LBO charms. It is a giant global company with a long-term record of sizable and stable cash flows from some of the world's best-known brand names. It pays nearly $900 million in dividends annually. And there are ample opportunities to cut fat, he says.   "If you believed Kimberly is well positioned globally, and had good growth prospects in a lot of the developing markets, and is in the early stages of a restructuring efforts, you could easily put together numbers that justify a higher EV/Ebitda multiple," the analyst maintains.   A hypothetical bidder for Kimberly would find there's plenty room for improvement. In the nine months ended last September, sales rose a respectable 4.6% to $12.4 billion, but operating and net income each fell, respectively, to $1.5 billion, down 14%, and $1 billion, down 15%. However, results for the third quarter showed that management's "Strategic Cost Reduction Plan" -- instituted 12 months earlier --  seems to be biting: Quarterly net income per share rose for the first time in two years, to 79 cents from 68 cents.   Yet Kimberly's Ebitda margins are still about six percentage points lower than P&G's 25%, Hutson notes. So relatively small margin improvements could boost Ebitda growth disproportionately -- just the kind of thing LBOs and private equity buyers thrive on.   The purpose of this exercise is not to suggest that Kimberly will soon be the target of an LBO. Rather, Hutson's credit analysis implies Kimberly's stock is still potentially cheap -- if management can execute on cost cuts and get Kimberly to approach P&G standards.   The irony is that the share jump makes things tougher for them. If they don't deliver the promised restructuring and the stock begins to slip, it becomes a cheap stock to folks who think they can reorganize Kimberly successfully. Hence, the probability of an LBO rises. Hutson can't be the only person on Wall Street running the numbers on Kimberly.   ---   E-mail: vito.racanelli@barrons.com   (MORE TO FOLLOW) Dow Jones Newswires  January 13, 2007 00:06 ET (05:06 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Headline: Barron's(1/15) In Risky World, U.S. Is Better Bet
Story: (From BARRON'S)     By Michael Santoli   The only thing to fear, ultimately, is fearlessness: The greatest risks lay in markets that are priced as if they hold no risk.   Plenty of markets around the world that appear to be close to this condition. Yet the market for big U.S. stocks is not among them. Junk-bond yields suggest that investors believe corporate defaults are mere legend. Emerging-market stocks are hardly any cheaper than those of developed markets, despite political and "event" risks.   Here in the States, as many folks on Wall Street like to point out, shares of household-name companies have lagged other asset-classes badly. Hardly bargains, they're arguably less expensive versus peers in other major markets, given their demonstrated profit growth and stout balance sheets.   For the past two years, U.S. retail investors have poured vastly more money into foreign-stock mutual funds than domestic funds. Last year, nearly $140 billion -- or 90% -- of all inflows to stock funds went offshore. And small investors are doing what they always do, chasing last year's performers.   All else being equal, this is bullish for U.S. shares, as the little guy is usually a contrary indicator at important market turns, and bear markets tend not to strike until he's been hooked. Professional investors, in contrast, are largely "all in," with their cash levels low and surveys of the pros implying general optimism.   Among the most active buyers of stocks have been companies themselves, with record repurchase activity, and buyout firms, which are taking advantage of pliant debt markets to take companies private in large numbers and at high prices.   Morgan Stanley strategist Henry McVey has been calling the U.S. stock market "the best house in a bad neighborhood," -- meaning the most attractive market in a cash-saturated, generally overpriced world. Still, as one real-estate truism suggests, if you buy the nicest house in a poor neighborhood, it's unlikely to be spared if things take a turn for the worse; it may just lose less value than others as the owners await a new buyer. That's worth considering in a universe where global markets trade in near unison, and where leveraged, professional "fast money" is setting the marginal price.     Last week's downdraft in commodities spooked the U.S. stock market for a couple of days, as investors feared the kind of massive liquidation of commodities and related stocks that hit last spring and preceded the Dow's largest correction in four years. All one really needs to know about the investors' creed today is that liquidity is good, liquidation bad.   As commodity markets stabilized, stateside investors took to lifting the indexes ahead of earnings season. The indexes continue to hang tough and defy widespread calls for a cleansing pullback, even as the market presumably looks for an excuse to sell off after rising in 11 of the past 12 months.   The Dow made another all-time record last week, and the Nasdaq clicked to a six-year high. With large-tech stocks reasserting some leadership (the Nasdaq 100 is the best-performing index, year to date) and brokerage stocks have stayed firm, it remains the bulls' game to lose.   Be forewarned, however, that during this bull market the vast preponderance of upside has come outside of earnings-reporting seasons. Indeed, if the recent pattern holds, the next few weeks will see disappointers punished far more than overachievers are rewarded.     Teen retailer American Eagle Outfitters (ticker: AEOS) has been on a torrid run. In 2006, earnings jumped 34% and the share price more than doubled. It's one of the best-performing stocks of the past decade.   For such a well-managed, cash-rich, investor-pleasing company, AEO has drawn more than its share of enemies, all betting the mall-store operator will soon stumble. Only four of 27 analysts recommend the stock. Short interest has swelled from five million to 20 million shares since June, now accounting for 10% of all free-trading shares.   Yet sales momentum remains impressive, return on equity has surged, the company's standing is strong among fashion-conscious teens, and now a high-margin line of underwear and "dorm wear" is being rolled out.   True, AEO this year will be going up against tougher year-ago results. It had a 13% same-store sales gain in December. A stellar fourth-quarter earnings report is probably built into today's price. The price-to-earnings ratio, above 17, is higher than that of rival Abercrombie & Fitch (ANF). And a smattering of insider selling has lately hit the tape.   But all of this is already well-known. It looks from here as if the path to continued double-digit profit growth remains intact. This stock pits teenagers' brand loyalty against short-sellers' stamina. The shorts are often right, but they are also reliably early. Expect the kids to keep giving them fits for a while.   ---   For Barron's subscription information call 1-888-BARRONS ext. 685 or inquire online at http://www.barronsmag.com/subscription/subscription.html.     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  January 13, 2007 00:09 ET (05:09 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Story: Black: Bronco Drilling [BRNC] is a land-rig company -- another controversial sector. It came public in August '05 and was selling for 14.56 a share a Friday. It has 24.9 million fully diluted shares, a $362 million market cap. There is no dividend. Stated book is $13.71 a share. Tangible book is $12.72. Trailing-four-quarter return on equity is 22%. Net debt to equity is 0.18. With their cash generation, they'll soon be out of the banks completely, and have a debt-free balance sheet. Bronco has 52 land rigs operating in Oklahoma, Texas, the Rocky Mountains. Half its customers are publicly traded companies like XTO Energy [XTO], Chesapeake Energy [CHK] and Devon Energy [DVN]. The other 50% are large independents. Their average contract is about 8 1/2 months. Some contracts rolling off were made at lower rates of $16,000- $17,000 a day. The going rate now is $19,000 a day. Their land rigs are not high-end; most are not 2,500 horsepower. They're between 1,200 and 1,300. The company is going to add three more rigs this year.   Gabelli: These are shallow gas?   Black: Not terribly shallow. They can go down 10,000 to 15,000 feet. They supply the crews, as well. My estimates are conservative. Fifty-four rigs, on average, at $19,000 a day for 365 days gets you to $375 million of revenue. Operating expenses roughly run 49%. Depreciation, depletion and amortization runs $34 million and general and administrative expenses are $20 million. So, you have operating income of $137 million. Interest expense of $4 million gets you to $133 million, fully taxed at 37%. They will make about $84 million, or $3.35 a share on 25 million shares. Divide 14.56 a share by $3.35 and you get 4.3 times earnings.   Neff: I thought it's hard to find low-P/E stocks.   Black: It is increasingly difficult, except for micro caps. What happens if rates tank by $1,000 a day? That would cost Bronco 50 cents a share after taxes. If they drop to $17,000 a day, it would take them down by a buck. They would still have $2.35 a share in earnings. On a break-up-value calcu- lation -- you want to have asset protection, as well -- we get to $25.86 a share. With rates at $19,000 a day, Bronco has cash flow of $138 million. It will generate about $106 million of free cash. The company discounts all its projects at a 12% to 13% after-tax hurdle rate. The risk here is there may be a glut of land rigs. There is a glut of gas in the U.S. because of the warm weather, but the companies we own are still making quite a bit of money at $6 per mcf. The stock is selling below its IPO price of 17 a share, though it has been over 30. It is in the bargain basement.   Witmer: It sounds great.   Black: My next company is Home Solutions of America [HSOA], based in Dallas. It is a $5.67 stock, 47.1 million fully diluted shares. The market cap is $267 million. The company was formed in 2002 and has two businesses. Recovery and restoration contributes 69% of revenue, and rebuilding and remodeling 31%. Unfortunately, the stock is perceived as a play on hurricanes because the company did benefit from New Orleans, but it has an extensive backlog of business. Home Solutions cleans up after floods, fires and hurricanes. It does mold prevention, and asbestos and mold decontamination. On the rebuilding and remodeling side, it does specialty interiors, granite and marble countertops and cabinets. It sells its services through 125 Home Depot stores and handles mostly renovations, not new homes. The overall kitchen-renovation market was $38.7 billion last year.     Q: Is it also in Lowes?   Black: The company has started to penetrate Lowes [LOW]. It's in six stores. In recovery and restoration, its customers to a large extent are insurance companies and the federal government. Home Solutions operates in California, Texas, Louisiana, Mississippi, Alabama, Florida, Georgia and South Carolina. On a trailing-12-month basis, ROE was 20.7%. Figure they'll do about $215 million in revenue this year, compared with $155 million in 2006. They have about 20% organic growth. About $25 million of Katrina-related business was pushed from the fourth quarter into 2007. They had operating margins of 27.1% in the most recent quarter, so we held them at that. They generate $58 million in operating income and have only $3 million in interest expense. Fully taxed at 37%, they will earn about 77 cents a share. That works out to a 7.4 multiple.   Neff: Will they be hurting in 2007 because there were no storms?   Black: They have a backlog of business. New Orleans hasn't been rebuilt. There is work in California and Florida. Net debt to equity at year end was about 0.1. They had $17 million in net debt on $167 million of equity. They'll generate about $23 million of free cash flow.   My next pick, Altra Holdings [AIMC], just came public. It's based in Quincy, Mass. The company was formed a few years ago. It's a spinout from Danaher [DHR] and the management came from Ingersoll Rand [IR]. The stock is 13.85. Fully diluted, there are 23.1 million shares outstanding. The market cap is $320 million.   Gabelli: What was the IPO price?   Black: It came public at 13.50. There are two major product lines: mechanical power transmission and motion-control products. It's not sexy, just heavy manufacturing --  industrial clutches and brakes, gear drives, couplings, engineered bearing assemblies. In more than 50% of their product line, they have the No. 1 or No. 2 market share. They are not heavily dependent on the automotive sector and don't even sell directly to the Big Three [General Motors, Ford and Chrysler]. Altra's key businesses are energy, 9%; agricultural and mining machinery, 7%; general industrial, 24%; material handling, 19%. From a geographic standpoint, 71% of revenue comes from North America and 29% is foreign. They have manufacturing facilities in the U.K., China and Heidelberg, Germany, Toronto and the U.S. About 37% of sales go through distributors like W.W. Grainger [GWW], and 53% are original equipment sales.     Q: What do earnings look like?   Black: For 2006, revenue was about $476 million, and earnings were $57 million. Altra thinks it can grow the top line by about 8% this year, to $514 million. Ebitda margins are running in the mid-15% range. Depreciation and amortization is $14 million, which gets you to $64 million pretax. They have high interest costs of about 9.5%, on average, because they have some legacy debt from Genstar, a private-equity firm. So $19 million in interest gives you profit before taxes of $45 million. Taxed at 37.5%, with 23.1 million shares, you get $1.22 a share of earnings. The P/E is 11.3.   By year end the debt-to-equity ratio will drop to 1.6. Altra will have free cash flow of about $24 million. This year, return on equity will be 29.8%. Return on total capital is 11.5%. Management owns the stock, and Genstar still owns about 30%.     Q: What sort of appreciation do you see?   Black: The multiple could expand to 15 if they deliver the numbers. That could take the stock to 18-19. Arrow Electronics [ARW], which I used in the midyear Roundtable, is one of the best tech stocks that still is reasonable: It is a major distributor of electronics. The stock is 33.96. There are 122.2 million fully diluted shares and a market cap of $4.15 billion. Arrow has 250 sales facilities worldwide, and 19 distribution and value-added centers in 53 countries. The sale of electronic components accounts for 81% of revenue, and computer-related products 19%. Revenue in the first nine months of 2006 was up 22.9%, operating income was up 34.5%, and earnings per share were $2.12, against $1.48. For the full year, revenue was about $13.6 billion, and they earned $2.90 a share. Revenue prior to two acquisitions could grow 8%. With 4.8% operating margins, you get an estimated $705 million in operating income. Interest expense is $104 million. An equity pick-up and a joint venture of $6 million, fully taxed, get you to $3.33 a share.     Q: What did they buy?   Black: A small company, InTechnology, in the U.K., which sells computer-security and enterprise-solutions products. It will add $400 million of revenue and $4 million in after-tax earnings, or two to four cents. The bigger purchase is KeyLink Systems, which they bought from Agilysis in Cleveland. It adds $1.6 billion in revenue and will add 18 to 22 cent a share in earnings. After acquisitions, the company could have $16.7 billion of revenue, net income of $435 million and earnings per share of $3.55. The stock sells for 9.6 times earnings.   Archie likes small banks. My last pick, Severn Bancorp, [SVBI], is in Annapolis. It has three branches, all in Anne Arundel County, in Maryland, and is about to open a fourth. It pays a small dividend, 24 cents a year on an 18.70 stock, for a yield of 1.3%. There are 9.15 million fully diluted shares, and a market cap of $171 million. As of Sept. 30, total assets were $910 million. The trailing-12-month return on equity was 21%. Return on assets was 1.85. Book value is $9.10 a share, with zero goodwill. Reserves are $8.65 million and non-accrued loans are $3.46 million, so they are reserved 2.5-to-1. The company's goal is to be in the top 10% to 15% in ROA and ROE of the whole bank universe. Their efficiency ratio [expenses as a percentage of revenue] is off the charts, at 33.95%. For the first nine months of '06 they did $1.32 a share, against $1.16.   This is a savings bank, but only 23% of the loan portfolio is residential. Forty-two percent is construction and development, and commercial real estate is another 18%. Only 31/2% of the portfolio is in home equity.     Q: What has loan growth been?   (MORE TO FOLLOW) Dow Jones Newswires  January 13, 2007 00:04 ET (05:04 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Headline: Barron's(1/15) Profile: Mid-Caps, Big Gains
Story: (From BARRON'S)     By J.R. Brandstrader   Fred A. Kuehndorf   Portfolio Manager: Dreyfus Premier S&P   STARS Opportunities T Fund     Fred Kuehndorf builds a portfolio the way the Swiss make watches: He carefully chooses components from only the highest-quality parts. Then he narrows the selection further using his own technique.   The process seems to work: Through year-end 2006, Kuehndorf's Dreyfus Premier S&P STARS Opportunities T Fund (ticker: BSOAX) ranked in the top 4% of all mid-cap-growth offerings over three years with a 16% annualized gain-versus the 13.08% average for its peers-according to Morningstar, which gives it a four-star rating. Last year, its 11.9% return didn't keep pace with 2005's stellar 20.7% gain, but was strong enough to place it in the 28th percentile in its category. A hefty 4.5% front load and a 1.61% expense ratio haven't stopped money from pouring in.   Kuehndorf doesn't agree with Morningstar's or Lipper's categorization of STARs as a mid-cap growth fund. He sees it, ore precisely, as "a core fund with a growth tilt" that reflects his experience.   He peruses the highest-ranked (virtually all the five-star) stocks as rated by Standard & Poor's stock-appreciation ranking system, or STARS. From this group, he chooses among the firms he thinks are best allocating capital. Then he takes his selections to his employer, The Boston Company Asset Management, a unit of Mellon Financial. There, the appropriate analyst offers further opinions.   That methodology hasn't changed much since Dreyfus took the then-three-year old fund over from Bear Stearns Asset Management in 2004, as part of a larger acquisition of Bear Stearns funds.   Along with strong relative returns since Kuehndorf took the helm in 2004, assets have swelled to $220 million, from $45 million in 2004. After reviewing all the fund's holdings at the time of the acquisition, he decided to keep many of the stocks as he rebalanced the portfolio. Turnover generally is a modest 32.78%.   "We typically initiate positions at 2% [the fund totals about 50 stocks ], and we let the winners run," he says. The average market cap is about $7 billion. More generally, "you are investing in companies at a great point in their evolution, because they have grown past the point where they can be squashed by a competitor," he says. They also are less likely than large-caps to grab headlines with excesses like oversized executive payouts.   The recent increase in mergers and acquisitions could also help the fund, because S&P's discounted cash-flow models "historically have been good at identifying takeover candidates," he says.   Celgene (CELG) is one of Kuehndorf's perennial favorites. Shares of the Summit, N.J., company have soared most recently on the Food and Drug Administration's approval of its drugs Thalomid and Revlimid to treat a blood cancer known as multiple myeloma. "They are generating a lot of cash flow, and the growth in cash flow should be pretty nice," he says. The stock was one he decided to hold on to back in 2004 at $13; it was recently quoted at 56.   One of his first additions to the fund in 2004 was Coach (COH), the New York-based maker of pricey handbags and accessories. Kuehndorf bought it at 20.60; it was trading last week at 45.65, and he thinks Coach has "plenty of room to expand its operations in the U.S., Japan and China" and can still improve its margins.   In October, he purchased shares of PMI Group (PMI), a Walnut Creek, Calif., mortgage-insurer, at 44.50. "Because of the concerns over housing, the stock is trading below liquidation valuation, and we are not as concerned about credit quality as the market," he says. PMI has since moved above 47.   Another 2006 pick was Harris Corporation (HRS), a communications-equipment maker based in Melbourne, Fla., that supplies about a third of the military radios worldwide. The company is expected to benefit from increased spending on radios from the U.S. Defense Department. In addition, says Kuehndorf, "Forty percent of the business is international, and they are getting a big order from Pakistan." He acquired shares in May at 42.08; they were trading at 50.18 last week.   A University of California, Santa Barbara, grad with an MBA from Wharton, Kuehndorf got his first experience in this portion of the market in the mid-'90s, when he ran a mid-cap growth fund for Deutsche Bank Private Bank. He left Deutsche Bank to oversee a mid-cap institutional fund for Ashland Management. He joined Dreyfus toward the end of 2002. Three years later, Dreyfus and The Boston Company combined their equity units.   Kuehndorf's preference for the middle way extends beyond finance. He and his wife, Aimee, chose Westport, Conn., to raise their children, John, 5, and Elizabeth, 2, because it isn't strictly urban or rural. And his house is centrally located, a mile-and-a-half from the train, the beach and the middle of town.   Then again, he hopes his portfolio performance never reverts to the mean.   ---   J.R. Headline: Japan Fujiya To Compensate Some Franchise Stores -Kyodo
Story: NEW YORK (Dow Jones)--Major Japanese confectioner Fujiya Co. (2211.TO)  has decided to compensate some of its 700 franchise shops across the nation for suspending businesses following a revelation that it has shipped cream puffs made from old milk, the Kyodo news agency reported Saturday, citing company officials.   Since Thursday, Fujiya has suspended operation of all of its five factories and about 890 confectionary shops and restaurants, Kyodo reported. The company says the operation will resume after quality control is reestablished, the report said.   Most of Fujiya's confectionary shops are franchise stores, which number 707, the report said.   The officials said the company will determine the amount of compensation to the franchise stores by considering the size of sales and other factors, the report said.   Confectionary sales are Fujiya's mainline operation, accounting for about 30% of its entire sales, Kyodo reported. By suspending the business, Fujiya loses about JPY60 million to JPY70 million yen in revenue each day on weekdays and around JPY100 million each holiday, the report said.   If the sales suspension is prolonged and consequently compensation costs swell, there will be a significant adverse impact on the company's earnings, analysts said, the report said.   The company's in-house investigation found the same day that eggs that were a day past the use-by date had been used in making cream puffs at its factory in Niiza, Saitama Prefecture a few years ago, the officials said, according to Kyodo.   Separately, at the company's factory in Sapporo, Hokkaido Prefecture, an on-the-spot investigation by the Sapporo city health center the same day found that the way the factory keeps records on food materials failed to meet the city ordinance on food hygiene, Kyodo reported.   Inundated with complaints about its quality control and questions over its future business course, Fujiya has refrained from running TV commercials on its chocolate and other products since Thursday, the report said.     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  January 13, 2007 02:48 ET (07:48 GMT)

Headline: Barron's(1/15) Plugged In: Dialing Down IPhone's Goals
Story: (From BARRON'S)     By Mark Veverka   What doesn't happen in Vegas still plays in Vegas.   The biggest story at this year's Consumer Electronics Show in Sin City was the splashy introduction of Apple's iPhone, which was actually unveiled at the MacWorld Expo in San Francisco. The two consumer confabs overlapped, prompting a significant number of CES goers to hop 90-minute flights to San Francisco on Tuesday for Apple CEO Steve Jobs' dramatic keynote address.   As most of us know by now, Apple (ticker: AAPL) introduced a mobile smartphone about the size of its video iPod that makes telephone calls, plays music and videos, searches the Web and fetches email. Its sleek design and cool features, such as touch-screen controls, has gadget hounds frothing.   But the most important revelation, perhaps, is the fact that Apple struck a deal with AT&T's (T) Cingular wireless unit to be the chosen carrier to sell the handsets. The other option was for Apple to become its own Mobile Virtual Network Operator, such as DisneyMobile, which would have allowed the iconic consumer-electronics company to wield tighter control over its sales channel. One of the big advantages the iPod portable music player has enjoyed over rivals is its ability to sell directly over the Web and through Apple's company-owned stores.   Selling handsets through Cingular in conjunction with service contracts will be a totally different ball game for Apple, just one example of how Jobs' foray into mobile handsets is fraught with risk. (A bigger risk to Apple might be a reported federal securities investigation involving Jobs.)   Apple's shares shot up more than 7 points on the day after iPhone was unveiled, and were up nearly 11% by Friday, at about 94.50. The average target for the Street is about 100, meaning much of the phone's anticipated revenues are already baked into the current stock price.   The phone isn't especially cheap, either. At $499 for the 4-gigabyte model and $599 for the 8-gig version, iPhones will rank among the most expensive handsets on the market. Only 5% of the world's handsets wholesale for more than $300. On top of that, Cingular, which is now rebranding itself as AT&T, will require 2-year service contracts, which will cost iPhone voice and data users about $2,500. Plus, the iPhone will be largely ignored by deep-pocketed corporate-enterprise customers, whose employers' prefer BlackBerry's push e-mail software. (Last week's sell-off of BlackBerry-maker Research in Motion (RIMM) shares appears to have been an overreaction).   All of which makes Apple's goal of selling 8 million units for fiscal 2008 look extremely ambitious. Sanford Bernstein hardware analyst Toni Sacconaghi figures the company is likely to sell only 4.5 million units. He puts the fair value of Apple's shares at 95, about where they are now.   Nonetheless, the iPhone isn't good news for Motorola (MOT), Nokia (NOK), Samsung (005930.Korea), Palm (PALM) and Sony-Ericsson. Motorola has seen mixed results from its music-enabled handsets, such as the iTunes-enabled ROKR and the multimedia KRZR, while Nokia has unveiled new digital-media handsets that look remarkably similar to Motorola's super-thin RAZR. Motorola recently warned that revenues were lighter than expected, indicating that handset prices have been squeezed to keep unit-volume strong. It will be interesting to see how long the iPhone remains priced at a half-grand.   ---   For Barron's subscription information call 1-888-BARRONS ext. 685 or inquire online at http://www.barronsmag.com/subscription/subscription.html.     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  January 13, 2007 00:08 ET (05:08 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.
